DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a corrigendum to the explanatory memorandum to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986 is an omnibus Bill which amends the Social Security Act and various pieces of legislation affecting veterans' entitlements. It not only represents changes to social welfare and veterans legislation in Australia but also gives the people of Australia and the members of this House an insight into the attitude of this Government to welfare. It also gives them an insight into this Government's lack of economic policy. That lack of economic policy-the Government's failure in that area-is illuminated in its failure in social welfare policy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that in the Budget social security expenditure went up by $1.1 billion. But, instead of that being greeted with support from the welfare lobby in the community, it was attacked. The measures introduced by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) were attacked, were criticised, were analysed in detail by the Australian Council of Social Service and found to be wanting. It is no wonder that they were found to be wanting-they are totally inadequate. They are totally inadequate not only in the way that they will operate but also in terms of the promises and expectations that were raised by this Government, before it was elected, in its dealings with those people in the community who are perhaps less fortunate and in need of greater help.

It is instructive to look at the attitudes of this Government and the expectations that it raised before coming to office. It is important to understand the betrayal that this legislation represents to understand why this Government will be tossed out at the next election and why we will be able to count on one hand the number of pensioners who will vote for the Government. In 1983 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in a policy speech:
I am not in the business, and the Labor Party is not in the business, of making promises that cannot be fulfilled.

Some of the promises made bear directly on social security legislation. Perhaps the most important promise he made in the context of this Bill was that his Government would eliminate the lag in consumer price index adjustments for pensions. He said that his Government would decrease the lag from four weeks to one week. He also said: `I am not in the business of taking money out of pensioners' cheques'. In 1983 he made a firm promise that he would eliminate the lag in CPI adjustments. We had the 1983 Budget, the 1984 Budget and the 1985 Budget, and the lag still exists. What happened with the 1986 Budget? This Government moved to increase the lag in consumer price index adjustments for pensions-after the Prime Minister said in 1983: `I'm not in the business of making promises that won't be fulfilled' and `I won't take money out of pensioners' cheques'. No wonder the pensioners of this country have had enough of this Government. They began to be disillusioned when the Government introduced the assets test and introduced the means test for pensioners over 70 years of age, when it robbed their pocket money by withdrawing the income concessions, sneakily reducing it last year. The Minister must be embarrassed. He knows the significance of knocking off the incentive effect for people on limited incomes. He ran around like a chook without a head-or, perhaps, a Minister without a policy-saying: `We will do something about it; we are looking at a new scheme'. In February of this year he said: `We are consulting widely and we will have a new scheme'. The Budget has been and gone; we still do not have a new scheme. We are still taking the pocket money of pensioners; we are still making it hard for them to earn a few dollars extra, to have a bar of chocolate or maybe a bit of fruit for the sideboard. We still have a massive disincentive effect.

What that really represents for the pensioners of Australia is a massive betrayal. It also indicates the priorities of the Australian Labor Party. It feels that it has the welfare vote locked up. Let me tell the Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, and all the other members of the Australian Labor Party, particularly those back bench members in marginal seats, that the welfare vote is not locked up. Welfare recipients are not stupid. They know the real priorities of the Labor Party-power at any price. The Government says: `Tell them anything and hope they forget about it, but make sure that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the rest of us on the front bench are comfortable, make sure that our political priorities are in place and that we maintain power at any price, and make all the promises in the world and hope that no one writes them down and quotes them to us'. Unfortunately, that does not work. It might have worked when the present Prime Minister was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, when he could go into a Press conference and bully people and perhaps no one would question what he said. But unfortunately in this place it is all written down. Also, when someone makes a policy speech, some people accept that and believe that what someone says he will do he will do. When he does not deliver they become disenchanted.

Madam Speaker, you will notice that precious few members of the Government are in the chamber today. It is no wonder; they are embarrassed at the duplicity of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Social Security, because this Bill we are considering today represents an abject failure on the part of the Minister. It represents tangible evidence of his lack of effective policy and his lack of clout within Cabinet. Quite frankly, contrary to the public relations which says that there will be equality of sacrifice, there is not equality of sacrifice in this legislation. The people in our society who can least afford to make sacrifices are being called upon to make great sacrifices.

The cost of this CPI deferral, which was not going to happen-in fact, the lag was to be reduced-according to the Australian Council of Social Service for a single pensioner is $49.80 in a full year and $83 for a married couple. That is a fairly significant cost for people on limited incomes, people who are suffering as a result of high rates of inflation. It is also a very significant cost, considering that this very same Government-this Government that does not make promises that cannot be fulfilled and is not going to take money out of the cheques of pensioners-also promised to increase the age pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Of course, it is nowhere near that. Not only was it nowhere near that a couple of months after the promise was made; it is nowhere near it 3 1/2 years down the track. The Australian pensioners have been waiting 3 1/2 years for the Prime Minister of Australia, the Minister for Social Security and the Australian Labor Party to deliver on their promises. Let me tell those pensioners who are listening to this debate today that they will be waiting for a long time yet, because this Government has no intention of honouring those promises or any of the other promises that it makes. The Government scatters promises around this country like confetti, knowing full well that it cannot meet them and that it has no intention of meeting them, and hoping that people will forget them.

I mentioned that social security expenditure in this Budget had gone up by $1.1 billion. Many people believe that we are in fact spending more now and doing less good. Despite the Government's rhetoric about expenditure restraint and a determination by its publicists to create the impression in the community that social security expenditure had been reduced by $500m, it has gone up, and people still do not believe that there is an effective social security policy, because the money is not being spent effectively.

The Bill also changes the provisions relating to family allowances. There is now an income test on family allowances for children over 16. Family allowances and the allocation for the double orphans pensions are the only benefit categories within the Department of Social Security that have suffered a reduction in expenditure. That again evidences the Government's priorities. Family allowances and double orphans pensions have dropped and other benefit categories have gone up ever so slightly, some more than others. But the Government does not appreciate that the cost of raising children continues right through the period in which they are dependent. Once they reach the mid and late teens the cost of looking after them increases. This Government, with its great commitment to the youth of Australia that we have seen through the failed Priority One: Young Australia program, introduces an incomes test for student children or children 16 years and over-the very time in a family's development when there is a need for help to ensure that young people can remain at school and in training. The Government must recognise the significant costs involved in raising teenage children.

The Government needs a much better policy on family allowances and support, but is devoid of policy. We are told that in the next couple of weeks we shall see a statement on family support and assistance, but that is all we shall see-a statement. This Government has been in office since March 1983 and there has been no significant reform of the social security system. There has not been a significant policy statement. All that has happened is the appointment of a number of consultants to work out a policy for the Australian Labor Party, which has based part of its political credibility on having an effective social welfare policy. We have seen a continuation of ad hoc measures, trimming and tucking here and there to save a couple of hundred million dollars, without concern for the consequences or any understanding of the flow-on effects, the incentive and disincentive effects or the social consequences of changing the benefit trail.

It does the Minister no credit to come into this House from time to time and to challenge me to policy debates when he knows that he has no policy to debate. He relies on outside consultants and appoints them only because probably somebody has said to him: `You have been in office for some two years and Labor still does not have a policy. We may have an election and somebody may ask what our policy is and what we have done in social security in our 3 1/2 years of office'. The answer is that nothing has been done. There is no effective policy. That is why there is immense pressure on the social security review to come up with discussion papers. The first draft was received and people looked at it and said: `No, we cannot bring this out. Go back and rewrite it'. That is why there are so many delays. I expect the Minister for Social Security and the Government to lay down firm directions and to set guidelines for the review to let the people know what are the Government's intentions in that regard. Frankly, we do not know the Government's intentions or priorities. We have seen a few ideological statements, a bit of rhetoric, but no firm statement of objectives.

One of the other statements made by the Prime Minister in his 1983 policy speech was that his Government would eliminate poverty traps. It is interesting to examine the history of legislation designed to that end. After the National Taxation Summit, the ill-starred fiasco that took place in this chamber, there were proposals to change the tax laws. Consequent upon those proposals was a need to change the interaction of the social security legislation and the Income Tax Assessment Act. So in October 1985 the Minister brought in legislation known as the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill. Although it was not perfect, that legislation had support from both sides of the chamber. We said that it was a step in the right direction and we invited the Government to bring it in more promptly than it proposed.

The Government introduced the legislation in October 1985 and it passed through the Parliament in November 1985, but the Government said from the very beginning that it had no intention of implementing it until November 1986. With the benefit of hindsight, one wonders what the Government was planning. It brought in the legislation, waved it around the place but said that it would not do anything about it until November 1986. That was very convenient because we now find that that legislation has been deferred. Had it been brought into effect, it would have been much harder to defer. It has now been deferred, not until November 1986, but until July 1987. I wonder whether we will ever see that legislation implemented.

Perhaps the worst and most hypocritical aspect of this, which evidences the double standards of the Australian Labor Party, is that this Government proposes to continue with the changes to the income tax scales of this country. The changes to those scales were part and parcel of the package which brought about the poverty traps reduction legislation. Thus those Australians in work, earning an income, with a standard of living higher than that of people on welfare, will receive some sort of tax cuts-albeit it token cuts that will be eroded by fiscal drag and the rate of inflation. But what happens to those clients of the Department of Social Security? Nothing. Their relief, their incentive measure, has been deferred until July 1987. This is the Government that claims to look after those people in need in our community. The Government thinks that it has the welfare vote wrapped up. Let me tell it: It cannot fool all the people all the time. The pensioners of Australia have woken up to the Government and the other clients of the Department of Social Security are waking up rapidly. They know about the double standard; they are aware of the consequences of providing tax cuts for one group in the community and no help for anybody else. They are aware of that double standard and they know what it will mean for their living standards. We see this all the time. By the way, the cost of this deferral will be up to $320 for a single pensioner and $640 for a married couple. It is blatant discrimination.

We see this again in the confused response that the Minister has given to the consequences of the Treasurer's economic policies. In this Bill we see a proposal to increase the rental assistance threshold from $10 to $15. Under the economic policies of the Treasurer we have seen the greatest increase in rents in Australia's history. As a consequence of the Treasurer's ban on negative gearing, his capital gains tax and his absolutely total reliance on a tight monetary policy giving us record high real interest rates, rent values in Australia have been forced to unprecedented levels and the vacancy rate has been reduced to an historic low. When it costs the earth to rent a flat, to put a roof over one's family's head, when it is difficult to get a flat anyway because there are not many vacant ones available, this Government increases the threshold for the payment of rental assistance. Quite frankly, I do not think that many people who are eligible for that assistance or many people who understand social welfare policy in this country will think that that is a very consistent approach. It would do the Minister much more credit to argue against some of the Treasurer's policies-to suggest that he do away with negative gearing and the capital gains tax and get away from the reliance on high interest rates policy-just like his left wing colleague in the New South Wales Parliament, the Hon. Frank Walker. It would be far more appropriate for the Minister for Social Security to be a bit realistic in his approach to economic policy and publicly support the statements made by the New South Wales left wing Labor Minister on this issue. Frank Walker is no fool-he knows what the problems are and he knows the changes that have to be made.

This Bill also makes certain changes to the administrative arrangements for the payment of unemployment benefits and supporting parent benefits. Of course, this Government has an appalling record on fraud and overpayment. It is absolutely appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—It does the Minister no credit at all to laugh. It is to his eternal shame that he has brought the social security system into complete disrepute and affected the status of those genuine clients of the Department. Let me talk about what this Government is purporting to do. It is classic tokenism and another example of treating the Australian people as complete fools. The Government is talking about imposing in this legislation a requirement for people claiming unemployment benefits to be registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service. I have no argument with that at all. I firmly support the view that those people on unemployment benefits should be available for work and actively seeking work. Unlike the Minister, I believe that people on unemployment benefits should return some service to the community in return for that benefit. What the Minister does not really appreciate is that the people of Australia understand that in the operating manual of the Department of Social Security there has always been a requirement for those people on unemployment benefits to be registered with the CES.

SPEECH.PARA: The only problem was that the requirement could never be enforced because this Minister allowed the Department's administrative procedures to run down, because there was a continuing brawl between the Department of Social Security and the CES and because the CES has totally inadequate records. Instead of having computer records, all its records are on cards. How it can match, on a fortnightly basis, 600,000 people from a card records system against a sophisticated computer records system in the Department I do not know. We now have a legislative requirement. That is fine-the Opposition does not oppose that at all. We just doubt that the Minister and his Department will be able to enforce that requirement any more effectively than the previous administrative arrangements. Yet the people of Australia are told that because it is legislative it will work.

In the same Press statement in which the Minister talked about anti-avoidance measures, he announced changes for the reporting requirements for supporting parent benefits. I remind honourable members that the big initiative for unemployment beneficiaries was a legislative requirement. In the same statement the Minister said `We are going to do something to make sure that the reporting requirements for supporting parent beneficiaries are changed and tightened'; but that is not a legislative change, it is an administrative change. Administrative requirements for unemployment beneficiaries do not work, but the Government thinks that they are fine for supporting parent beneficiaries.

This is just another example of this Government's double standards; another example of the Government trying to pull the wool over the people's eyes. Quite frankly, it will not work. The Government is either fair dinkum or it is not. It really does not have much chance of succeeding when it brings in such contradictory measures in the one Bill. The measures are juxta-posed and anyone who can read can see the difference in standards. If the Government were serious about returning credibility to the system, and if it were serious about doing something for the community's attitudes towards clients of the Department of Social Security, it would be a lot more frank in its approach to fraud and overpayment measures. It would not rely on the techniques of the right wing of the Australian Labor Party and it would not indulge in public relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your personal view on the ID card?
—It would make a frank statement about what it is going to do-a statement which says: `We have a problem and we will fix it'.
—The ID card?

—`Quite frankly, if we do not succeed the first time, we will continue to try.' The Minister is taunting me about my views on the identity card. The Minister knows, because he does not support the ID card, that it will not work. The Minister approved the submission of the Department of Social Security which said that no financial benefit would be anticipated to the Department from the introduction of the ID card.
—I thought you were opposed to fraud?

—I am opposed to fraud, but I know, like the Minister, that the ID card will not do anything about fraud in the Department of Social Security. I am prepared to stand here and say that, and I challenge the Minister to stand up and say that he knows also that ID fraud is not the major problem with the Department of Social Security and recognises also that the proposals for the ID system, or the Australia Card, will do nothing to help solve the problems of his Department. The Minister has been taken along in the current by the rest of his colleagues, again as part of the right wing push to be seen to be doing something. The Minister should be a lot more frank about these attitudes. I think it is appropriate for him to state on the record what his attitude is, as Minister for Social Security, to the proposed ID card and to clarify exactly what it will do for fraud and overpayment in his Department. It is in the submissions-the Minister has given his approval to it in the submissions-and it is about time that he said it personally.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation also makes further changes to the assets test. We have had about five versions of the assets test-I guess that the changes contained in this Bill represent about the sixth version-and it still does not work. Of course, the thing that has to be noted about these changes is that there is an alignment between the definition of `curtilage' under the assets test and the definition of `curtilage' under the capital gains tax legislation. I say no more than that. It is just an alignment of definitions of `curtilage' and `assets' between the Social Security Act and the tax legislation of this country.

In passing, it is also appropriate to note that this Government has collected a massive file on the assets and incomes of Australia's retired people. When the Government introduced the assets test, part and parcel of its statements was a guarantee that this information would never be used for tax purposes and that it would be kept secure. In recent weeks we have seen that it has never been kept secure. We have seen an alignment of definitions between tax legislation and the assets test legislation. We know that the Minister for Social Security and some of his advisers are dead keen on having a wealth study done in this country as the basis of a proposal for the introduction of wealth taxes. Given the Prime Minister's record on promises and given the flagrant disregard of any obligations that the Government may have incurred to the people of Australia along its political road, quite frankly, I wonder whether we can believe that this Government will never use the information that it has collected under the assets test legislation for tax purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you in favour of equity of sacrifice?

—The Minister seems to think that he has a monopoly on compassion. Quite frankly, he does not have a true understanding of the needs of people in less fortunate circumstances than perhaps him. If he had he would have fought a lot harder for the necessary changes within the Department of Social Security. The greatest betrayal that has taken place in recent years of clients of the Department of Social Security was the failure to adhere to the timetable for introducing poverty trap reduction measures, and the Minister knows it. It was an abject failure. He has allowed this Government to provide tax reductions for those Australians with a relatively high income and a relatively high standard of living and he has caved in on poverty trap reductions. He has allowed the Prime Minister to go back on a firm committment.

SPEECH.PARA: One would think that, in Cabinet, a statement by the Prime Minister in a policy speech that the Government would do away with the lag on the consumer price index adjustment and that it would increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings would give this Minister the ammunition he needs to win. But of course it has not. That says something, first of all, about his commitment and, secondly, about his effectiveness. Quite frankly, those two issues, which are fundamental to the well-being of many Australians and to which there is ample evidence of an initial commitment on the part of the Government-unless we believe that the Prime Minister had no intention at any time of introducing these measures and he was simply mouthing the words-should have allowed a Minister with a genuine commitment, a Minister who was committed to looking after his constituency, to achieve the right result. But of course that did not happen. He will pay the price for it, just as this Government will pay the price for it. Not only the marginal seat holders on the back bench of the Australian Labor Party will go, because, quite frankly, the Australian people have had enough. We will not see swings of 2, 3, 4 or 5 per cent; we will see swings like those we have seen in New South Wales recently-swings of up to 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!
—The honourable member should not scoff about it because he knows that it has happened.
—Dream time.
—What does the honourable member need to lose his seat-5, 6 or 7 per cent? Not as much as that.
—I will not lose it. I will be here next time.

—That will be the day. The honourable member will not be here next time. He will not be sitting over there. About the only person who will be sitting over here will be the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), as shadow Treasurer. As I have said, the Opposition is appalled at the duplicity contained in this Bill. We are appalled at the betrayal of those Australians in need. We are appalled that this Government does not have an effective social security policy. We are appalled at the ineffectiveness of the Minister. We are appalled that he is not prepared to fight privately and publicly for his constituency. We are appalled that he is not prepared to stand up and be counted on significant issues such as the identification card. We are appalled that he sold out to the techniques of the right wing by adopting public relations in place of policy. For those reasons, Mr Deputy Speaker, we seek to amend the motion for the second reading. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`the House-
(1) condemns the Government for-
(a) its action in deferring all automatic pension increases due on 1 November 1986;
(b) its uncaring further eight month deferral of the poverty traps relief measures;
(c) its illogical means testing of family allowances for 16 and 17 year olds, and
(d) its lifting of the rent threshold before a person paying private rent can qualify for rent assistance;
(2) condemns the Government for persisting with its inequitable assets test on pensioners;

(3) lodges a strong protest over the Government's continued assault on veterans and war widows through further restricting access to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and freezing the maximum level of social security component where a war widow is also eligible for an aged pension;

(4) calls on the Government to ensure a voluntary clearance is obtained from the veteran before proceeding with a claim on the veteran's private health insurance and points out that this aspect of the Bill seeking recompense for veterans' hospital and medical costs constituted a breach of the fundamental obligation to look after those who served this country in the time of war, and

(5) condemns the Government for taking three and a half years to do anything about social security fraud and yet do nothing new or positive but relying merely on window dressing and public relations'.

The amendment will be seconded by my gallant and honourable friend the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). This Government has sought to guillotine the debate on this Bill today. It has sought to do so because it knows that it cannot handle a public debate on its social security policy. It is a wonder it did not seek to bring on the legislation on a non-broadcast day to keep it completely under covers because it is under attack from all sides. The Australian Pensioners Federation has announced a campaign of action. I have had representatives of the Australian Council of Social Service ring me to talk about what we can do to stop the Government going ahead with its intentions in this legislation. I would like to be able to table in this House the many hundreds of letters I am getting from concerned pensioners and other clients of the Department about the consequences of this Government's policy. I would also like to be able to table some of the letters I get about fraud and overpayment and the blatant abuse of the system which has been allowed to go on under this Government's administration. Unfortunately, that is not possible.

It is not necessary to do that because every Australian understands the problems that have developed within the Department of Social Security under this Government's administration. They understand the Government's priority. Its priority is simply the retention of power at any price, without a genuine concern for the welfare of people in need. It seems to think that people's living standards can be lifted by glib statements and slick advertising programs. We are about to see between $2m and $5m spent promoting the fringe benefits tax. Let me tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we have not heard the end of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), asked why we brought on the Bill on a Friday, a broadcast day. I can say to him that we did that intentionally.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. I did not ask that question.
—There is no point of order. But, of course, it is a very touchy point with him.
—Order! There was a point of order if the honourable member claimed to be misrepresented. I call the honourable member for Canning.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the contribution of the honourable member he mentioned that we are debating this Bill on a broadcast day. I can tell him that one of the reasons for that is so that the people of Australia who listen to this broadcast can hear just what he said. If they listened to what he said, I can tell them what they did not hear; they did not hear anything about what the Opposition would do.

SPEECH.PARA: I will cover some of the points he raised. He talked about double standards. In recent times we have seen a classic example of double standards in this House. Just this week we brought in a tax avoidance measure to get back $900m. The tax avoiders of this country have been ripping off the system for years. In Question Time recently the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told how the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when he was Treasurer, received 28 memos from the Commissioner of Taxation pleading with him to do something about tax avoidance, but he did nothing in five years. When one matches tax avoidance with the effect that it has on pensions one can see some double standards. That piece of legislation I was talking about was opposed by honourable members opposite. As far as they were concerned, the $900m that was ripped off could stay with the rip-off merchants.

Another recent example was the stand that was taken by the Opposition in relation to the fringe benefits legislation. It was alluded to once again by the honourable member for Richmond in his contribution this morning. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said in the House the other day that the $700m that we would get from cutting out fringe benefits would pay for 140,000 pensions. That puts in perspective the arguments of those opposite when they talk about double standards. They will oppose everything that raises revenue from the people who can afford to pay that may be used to underwrite the social security provisions of this country. Not only that, but, in the context of double standards, the Leader of the Opposition and other Opposition spokesmen have made promises to the Australian public amounting to $5,900m. The Leader of the Opposition has also said he will have a zero deficit; that is, he will cut out the $3,500m. That amounts to $10,000m. But when we ask him where the money will come from, he does not know. He just says: `Oh, trust me'. When he goes on television and is asked questions about tax policy and a number of other things, he sits there like Marcel Marceau; he cannot say anything, he is like a mime. What is the use of going on television if he cannot tell people anything? The same thing occurred here this morning. We did not hear anything about the Opposition's policy on social security. I remind the House of what the Liberals did when they were in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a disgraceful record.

—The honourable member has said that they have a disgraceful record, and he is right. It is absolutely appalling. But the worst part about it from my point of view is the fact they used the welfare dollar as a massive pork barrelling exercise. We saw this again at the last election. I will remind the House of some of the things that the Liberals did when they were in power. I will not mention election dates, but if honourable members look at the changes the Liberals have made to the social security provisions, they can pick up those dates.

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1969 the tapered means test was introduced. This resulted in 160,000 existing pensioners receiving an increased pension. Some 33,000 pensioners became newly eligible for the pension and the pension was claimed by an additional 14,000 who were previously entitled to it. This was just in time for the 1969 election. In September 1972 there was an increase in the free area. This increased pension entitlements to all reduced rate pensioners and brought another 30,000 persons into pension eligibility for the first time, and another 20,000 persons who were entitled to a pension claimed it. Because it promised to be a close election there were also superannuation and annuity concessions in September 1972. The effect of this move was to increase the pension for 45,000 existing pensioners and to make an additional 5,000 eligible for a pension. We all know that the Liberals did not win that election. I think that was a bit of poetic justice.

Between 1973 and 1975 the Whitlam Government started to abolish the means test for pensioners over 75 years of age and then for the over-70s. It is apparent to those who follow election timings that these measures were not timed to coincide with the anticipated election dates. The 1973 and 1975 concessions were both two years away from elections had they been held on time. Of course, the Senate, not the Government of that era, determined the election dates. The abolition of the means test was compatible with the intent of that Government to introduce a national superannuation scheme, a feature of which was that it had no means test. The mistake of that Government was to abolish the means test before it had introduced the national superannuation scheme and not after. The events of 1975 meant that the Whitlam Government would never have that chance.

The next change occurred in November 1976. It altered the criterion from an assets test to an income only test. This was the most significant change and, as I will show later, it opened up a loophole that negated the original purpose of the pension system. Some 200,000 pensioners gained from the measure while 67,000 had their incomes, which should have been reduced, protected from any fall. Again, this was just in time for the 1977 election. In November 1978 a special income test on over-70s clawed back about $22m and affected 266,000 pensioners. But that take-back measure was two years away from the election. This approach was again evident in November 1982, when the family Budget-the honourable member for Richmond spoke about advertising campaigns to promote government initiatives, but we always remember the famous slick campaign to sell the family Budget just before the 1983 election-increased the free area and thereby increased the pensions of 420,000 people just before the Federal election. It happened again in 1984 when the Opposition ran its most scurrilous and gutless campaign on the assets test. The Leader of the Opposition, who was then the Treasury spokesman, did not speak out against the assets test, but those who knew his private views knew that he agreed with it because at least he had some economic literacy and could see the reason for an assets test. Of course, once he became Leader of the Opposition he embraced the assets test, and in fact it is the only promise the Opposition has kept in its proposed outlays.

The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) in his former capacity also spoke out in favour of the assets test, but when he came to this Parliament as a Liberal member he did a U-turn and started speaking out against it. I have said before and I will say again that the honourable member for Mayo has real leadership potential in the Liberal Party. Anybody who can do a U-turn in less than a year has to be pretty good. Morals go straight out the door; nothing is saved. John Elliott, Secretary of the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party, warmly embraces the assets test. We all remember that cynical television interview with Mr John Valder, who spoke of the necessary things that had to be done in government-the hard things, the things that the Labour Party has done in government. We introduced the assets test and got rid of pensions for millionaires.

When we talk about the welfare budget we should consider not only its size but also where the funds are going. We thought there was some obscenity in a situation where millionaires could get the pension while those people who relied on the pension as their only means of income were being denied an adequate amount. I have stated in the House before and I think it is worth stating again that when the coalition Government, following its election in November 1975, removed the assets test in November 1976, the single pension stood at 24.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. When the coalition Government was kicked out in March 1983, it had fallen to 22.7 per cent. That was the effect on pensioners of not having an assets test. Without an assets test there was a massive drop in the pension.

This Government had the guts to put the assets test back, and it wore all the flak for it, in its first Budget. Since then, the pension has climbed from 22.7 per cent of average earnings up to 24 per cent, and it will reach 25 per cent before the next election. Of that there is no doubt. Let us look at some of the views of the Opposition and the New Right on social security. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) is reported to have said in the Sun of 14 August 1986:
The Opposition would simply abolish benefits for the long-term unemployed if they got into power.
It would simply abolish them with nothing to replace them-no policy. The report continued:
In a weird twist of logic he said the Opposition's approach would be doing far more for the unemployed.

I agree with the Sun; it is a weird twist of logic. I just cannot see what he is getting at by saying that taking away the unemployment benefit is somehow helping the unemployed. I refer once again to John Elliott, the Federal Liberal Party Treasurer, who is trying to buy the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. He has not succeeded but he has got his British brewery. He called for the slashing of welfare expenditure in a speech to a Liberal Party luncheon in Brisbane. No specific areas were nominated. That fits in well with the sort of plan that the Opposition is running. It will not tell us about anything. John Elliott was reported by the Business Review Weekly to be earning $350,000 per year in 1984. On 30 July this year Elliott said that a Liberal Government would have to `get rid of some of the social programs.'

I have spoken before about the massive credibility gap of the Liberal Party. It has put forward an amount of $10,000m for which it has to produce answers. The Opposition spokesman on social security spoke about the fact that the Government takes the pensioner vote for granted. We have never done that. I ask how the pensioners of this country and anybody who receives social security think a coalition Government will maintain-not increase, but maintain-social security provisions with a massive credibility gap of $10,000m. It is just not possible. The social welfare area would be one of the hardest hit areas under a coalition Government. There is absolutely no question about that.

I turn to mention Andrew Hay, who is an interesting character. He is the bloke who races around the country with his high principles about the fringe benefits tax. Let us remember that the fringe benefits tax relates to free lunches, the hostess allowance, being able to run cars at company expense, overseas travel--

TALK.START.PARA: —Golf clubs.

—Yes, I hear that down in Melbourne it is now easier to get into golf clubs since we brought in the fringe benefits tax because companies are no longer paying golf club fees for their executives. All of those things are taken for granted by affluent people and supported by Andrew Hay. But what does he say about people at the other end? I am told that he is President of the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce. By God! He wants to dismantle our social security system. He has called for the abolition of family allowances, the slashing of youth employment training schemes, sharp cuts in payments to deserted spouses and limiting the payment of the unemployment benefit to those prepared to work for it. He does not mention how we differentiate between people who are prepared to work and those who do not. Let us look at what he is proposing, at the utter hypocrisy of what he is saying when he says: `We should keep the fringe benefits. We should keep all the rorts and ramps, the free business lunches'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take an example of following Mr Hay's philosophy of life. A pensioner who may go to a restaurant once a year, say with his wife on their anniversary, may sit next to Mr Andrew Hay and may even have the same meal. One thing about that is that the pensioner would pay 100c in the dollar for his bill but Mr Hay, under his scheme, would pay zero; the bill would go back to the company and the company would claim a tax deduction on it. In some ways we can see that the pensioner, if he were paying any tax, would in fact be subsidising Mr Hay. I think there is something obscene about that. The Labor Government has introduced measures, by the introduction of the assets test, the fringe benefits legislation and in stopping tax avoidance schemes, which will help the pensioners. In the contribution from the honourable member for Richmond this morning not only did he not tell us what the Opposition would do; he did not tell us how the Opposition would overcome its massive credibility gap. He did not speak about these sorts of things. He did not talk about free lunches for people such at Andrew Hay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hay is a member of the Liberal Party, is he?

—I think Mr Andrew Hay would be a member of the Liberal Party; he would fit in well. It would not be long before he came up here, I imagine, and joined that august collection of gentlemen on the other side. What about another Liberal Party person, Katharine West? There is a ray of light for you. She really comes up with some lulus. A headline in the Canberra Times was `Dole system ``out within a year'' '. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The present system of dole payments will be abolished within a year, political commentator Katharine West predicts.

She could not pick her nose. She is absolutely hopeless. Anybody who listens to Katharine West must be soft in the head. Let us look at another member of the Liberal Party-a disgraced Liberal this time, Mr Fraser. Here we have an article headed `Fraser's vision for the future'. It is good stuff. It is quite appropriate that this refers to his inaugural Downer lecture in Adelaide. I have spoken previously about the honourable member for Mayo, about his double standards and about how his acceleration through the Liberal Party should be enhanced by his moral manoeuvrability. Among other things, the article reports Mr Fraser as saying:
He proposed attacking wage costs by scrapping the 17.5 per cent holiday loading, reducing annual leave to three weeks and returning to the 40-hour week.

That is what we are supposed to need to get this country out of its mess. Let us remember that Mr Fraser was the gentleman who visited upon this country many of the economic ills that we face today because when he was in government he sat on his hands and did nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring back the lash, too.

—Yes, bring back the lash; he was into everything. But it was not enough that he got stuck into and started blaming the workers for all the ills of this country; he also got stuck into the pensioners. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The single parent's pension could be effectively abolished and that would save well over $1 billion.

He says that, yet he was in government for seven years and he did not abolish it. Now that he is an international statesman and he thinks that some people will listen to him, he says: `We will get rid of it. I never had the guts to do it when I was in government but the Labor Party can'. He is also reported as saying:
Unemployment benefits for 16 and 17-year olds should also be abolished.

What an absolute hypocrite he is to say those things now but never to have done them when he was in government. What did he do? If I have time, I will cite some figures from his last year in government. The fact is that his Government did nothing. All of our young people have a limited future because of the things that the coalition Government did not do when it was in government.

I also have an article headed `Libs want worker levy to pay welfare', with reference to the honourable member for Richmond. It would be bad enough if the Opposition were advocating that the cost of welfare be shared amongst the fringe benefits recipients. But now it wants the workers to pay for welfare. This Government does not like what it has had to do. It does not like asking the pensioners of this country to take a deferral in their pension increase. But the pensioners recognise that the economy has suffered a severe blow because of the narrow range of our exports and the effect on them of international prices. The pensioners of this country are willing to make a sacrifice. It is a very small one. We have not asked the pensioners of this country to take a discount in the way that we have asked the workers to do. We have kept our promise to the pensioners and we will continue to keep it. But the pensioners of this country are smarter than the Opposition thinks they are. We do not like doing these things but we know that the pensioners understand that.

Let us look at the record of the Liberal Party under Mr Fraser, who now advocates getting rid of some of the social security provisions. Under the Fraser Government the additional pension for children went down by 34.7 per cent, as did the mother's-guardian's allowance. Rent assistance went down by 2.1 per cent. The single adult unemployment benefit went down by 18.6 per cent and the junior unemployment benefit by 45.6 per cent. I know that other speakers on this side of the House will point out more of the hypocrisy and humbug that we have come to expect from the Opposition. All I can say in conclusion is that Moody's Investor Services Inc. got it right the other day. It gave this Government a AAA rating for its performance in government but it gave the Opposition a ZZZ rating for its non-performance in opposition. All I can say is that this Government will continue to look after those people in need-something that the Labor Party has always done when it has been in government-and we will not accept any of the hypocrisy that is thrown at us from the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), who has just concluded his speech, certainly strayed outside the ambit of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and focused on a number of matters particularly relating to the fringe benefits tax. Let me make it very clear that on this day a meeting is taking place here in Canberra to review that fringe benefits tax, forced by the strong opposition of the coalition to it. Our commitment on the fringe benefits tax is clear cut: We will abolish it lock, stock and barrel, as indeed we will abolish the assets test lock, stock and barrel.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendment that has been moved most comprehensively by my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). I support the remarks he made on this Bill. I point out that a number of my colleagues will be speaking in support of the amendment until the gag applies. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) will focus, amongst other things, on the discounting and deferment of increases in various entitlements for veterans. Also, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) will speak on the deferment of the poverty trap aspect of the legislation. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) will focus on the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme cutbacks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he well today?

—All of those measures amount to the assault on veterans, war widows and social security recipients embraced by this legislation. It ill becomes the honourable member for the very marginal seat of Bendigo to interject because he tried to mount a campaign saying that he had in some way succeeded in altering aspects of this Bill as it relates to war widows. But I have also been to Bendigo. I have met with the Returned Services League and war widow representatives from that centre and have had very comprehensive discussions with them. I will spell out, in the course of my communication, exactly what this Bill does to war widows and to veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the figures in relation to this legislation. The deferment of the consumer price index adjustment will take $4.8m from disability pension recipients in Bendigo and right around Australia. That will result from the failure to pass on that adjustment when it was due in early November and its deferment to much later in December. This measure will take $17.8m from service pension recipients in Bendigo and right around Australia. It will also take $3.7m from war widows right around Australia. That is the treatment this Government is meting out to those three categories of veterans' affairs recipients-a total of $26m from that one measure embraced by this Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill.

The removal of war widows from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme will also effectively remove some $3.81m that otherwise would have been paid to help war widows with their treatment under that scheme. I will not dwell on that. I move on to point out that the deferment of the poverty traps legislation will effectively mean $21m less for various categories of recipients in the veterans' affairs and social security areas. The freezing of the social security component of the pensions in cases where a war widow receives both a widow's pension and a social security age pension at $60.05 a week will bring a saving, according to the speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), of some $7.2m. In a Senate Estimates committee hearing I heard that this figure was put at $4.1m for the veterans' affairs area. I do not dwell on that except to ask that the exact saving in relation to that be clarified, because there seems to be a discrepancy between what the Minister said in Parliament when introducing the Bill and what was said by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) when he spoke before Senate Estimates Committee F and tabled certain information before it.

As the honourable member for Richmond correctly pointed out, this legislation brings about a wide range of cutbacks in relation to both social security and veterans' affairs. The mere fact that the veterans' affairs aspects have been bundled together with the social security legislation does not augur well. We have had the Government and now the Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, trying to conjure up a scare campaign about the future of the portfolio and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Here is the Government bundling into this Bill a series of amendments, including amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act, under the banner of social security. The reports in the media last week that somehow the Minister for Veterans' Affairs was to be demoted to a junior Minister by the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) under a proposal he was considering which would create an inner super-17 and an outer junior 10-with Veterans' Affairs falling in the outer junior 10-do not augur well in terms of what the Government has in mind for veterans.

In our consideration of this legislation, I could do no better than quote from someone at the grass roots level, a war widow who happens to live in north Rockhampton in Queensland. In a communication dated 9 October she said:

I wish to strongly voice my opposition as a War Widow that we have been taken from under the umbrella of the Veterans' Affairs and placed under the National Health Scheme in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

This is a gross injustice. Our husbands were promised the World when they joined up and as to be expected from heartless governments `kicked in the guts' on return and then when they are taken prematurely in death the boot is transferred to their widows.

I also voice my opposition to the dropping of the part aged pension to a pegged $60.05. This we feel is an imposition as we count our War Widows pension not as a pension but as a compensation for our husband's death and therefore we are entitled to an aged pension without this infamous pegging.
I ask you Sir, as a member of the Opposition in Federal Parliament that you strongly put my views . . .

I can do no better than put those views right here in this debate. I point out that that war widow comes from the very marginal seat of Capricornia. No doubt she will exercise her decision at the next Federal elections, because she has quite properly reacted to some of the provisions of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill.

Turning to the specifics of the legislation, I now focus on the recoupment of costs from private health insurance where a veteran has elected to take out that private health insurance. The amendment moved by the honourable member for Richmond includes the following statement:

The House . . . calls on the Government to ensure a voluntary clearance is obtained from the veteran before proceeding with a claim on a veteran's private health insurance and points out that this aspect of the Bill seeking recompense for veterans' hospital and medical costs constituted a breach of the fundamental obligation to look after those who have served this country in time of war.

I would like to read to the House a quotation which I have used on other occasions. It is from a former great Prime Minister of this nation, Prime Minister Ben Chifley. He told the House in respect of repatriation:

The careers of hundreds of thousands of young men have been interrupted and in some cases partially ruined. There is a break of education training and opportunity which cannot be repaired. It is perfectly true that experience is gained, but that is not material to an ordinary civil vocation. On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.

Today the Government is about to breach a fundamental obligation to the veterans by going into their health insurance. The Government of the same party as Prime Minister Ben Chifley will wind back on that fundamental obligation by deciding that, where a veteran has taken out health insurance voluntarily, it will not honour its obligation to meet the veteran's hospital and medical costs; it will go to HCF, MBF or whatever fund might be applicable and seek a recoupment of funds, which the Government should have supplied in the first place. I believe that is a very disgraceful aspect of this legislation. I believe also that it ought to be clarified in the course of the debate. I ask the Minister, in the course of his summing up, to place in Hansard very specific detail in relation to the voluntary aspects of this measure. I accept that the measure is voluntary in terms of a veteran's decision to take out private health insurance. That is one level, but my question relates particularly to the degree of voluntarism that will apply in the execution of this measure and whether every veteran will in fact be asked to sign an individual clearance on each occasion that a recoupment is being sought before the Government proceeds with collecting the funds through the very complex mechanism which has to be laid out because of problems with the Veterans' Entitlements Act and other legislation.

I ask the Minister to clarify in exact terms the voluntary aspect at both of those levels: The first level, taking out the health insurance; and, the second level, the individual execution administratively of that recoupment procedure. I also add that many veterans are very concerned because under their private health insurance they have only a certain number of physiotherapy treatments available in the course of 12 months. If the Government knocks off their entitlements in an early stage of the year they could be caught short and find themselves in a very embarrassing and financially desperate situation as an unintended consequence of this recoupment measure. So again I ask the Minister to explain to the House in detail the voluntary aspects of utilising this private health insurance recoupment provision measure under the provisions of this Bill.

Turning to the question of freezing at $60.05 the social security or aged pension component when a war widow receives both a war widow's pension and an age pension, I am advised this day that, as of August this year, the number of war widows in Australia was 67,860, and the number of war widows receiving also a social security pension was in fact 47,000. That is a very high percentage-well over half of all war widows-who will be affected by this freezing mechanism. Let us look at that freezing mechanism. I remind the House, the nation and the war widows of Bendigo that this Government originally proposed in its Budget a devilish manoeuvre which would have seen the level frozen at $60.05, a permanent reduction wherever a war widow receives some outside income. It would be reduced in such a way that they would never have been able to get back up to the $60.05. It was unjust, unfair and would have restricted them to the lower level for the rest of their lives. It shows the thinking of this Government when it was able to get this measure right through the Caucus, the Cabinet, the Budget drafting processes and into this House, and to announce it clearly in the detail of the Budget Papers. It was only after a concerted campaign at various levels that there was a second Budget backdown. The first backdown was in respect of those sometimes mollycoddled mandarins of Canberra who have concessional housing interest loans. I was pleased about that because there were onward ramifications for defence service home loans in that Budget decision. The Government backed down on concessional interest rates for certain public servants here in Canberra, and let us remember that the whole of this nation does not focus on Canberra and the realities of the nation are to be found far from Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —In places like Boree Creek.

—Yes, in places like Balranald, Berrigan, Boree Creek, Burraga and Buronga and elsewhere, including the River Murray in my electorate. The decision to freeze this provision is bitterly resented by war widows throughout Australia. It is resented notwithstanding the second Budget backdown whereby the permanent reducing maximum level has now been taken out of the legislation. I pay tribute to the War Widows Guild and many other veterans organisations on this outcome, and to one only Labor member, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who showed great courage in respect of this matter. I believe the campaign which was conducted by the Liberal and National parties helped bring about this reversal. It ill becomes the Government that it was drafted into the provisions in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to deal with the assets test aspect of this legislation. Again, the Government has changed the definitions of the test, which the coalition is committed to abolish lock, stock and barrel. It is time for us to examine the detail of the impact of the assets test in respect of veterans' service pensioners. The total of such pensioners a year ago exceeded 13,000, and the Government cannot produce figures later than 30 June 1985, due in part to industrial disputation. Twice I had the matter raised before a Senate Estimates committee and the best figures we have as to total number of veterans' service pensioners affected by the assets test is 13,381. I have a detailed State by State breakdown which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.
