—Heartless.

—It is heartless but, above all, it breaches the commitment given by governments of all political persuasions to look after those who served their country in time of war. It is that breach of commitment that is so bitterly resented by veterans and war widows. I shall continue to highlight that commitment at every opportunity as I move around as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I draw attention to the fact that this legislation includes the first lot of amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act since it was introduced and passed through Parliament-a long saga throughout the latter part of 1985 and the early part of 1986. Those amendments are largely technical and clarify the meanings intended in the principal legislation. They seek to ensure, for example, that members of philanthropic organisations such as the Salvation Army and the Red Cross receive repatriation cover where appropriate and desired. I mention that point particularly because in the other place we have obtained a commitment from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) that the Veterans' Entitlements Act and the guide to assessment of rates of veterans' pensions, which are causing a great deal of concern, will be referred to an independent monitoring committee to be set up in 1987 to ensure that the right thing is done by veterans. I strongly support the amendment moved by the coalition in respect of this important legislation-legislation which mounts a further assault on veterans, war widows, social security recipients. The Government should be ashamed of its action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. The Bill arises from the Federal Budget of 19 August and is a wide-ranging Bill which makes many changes in our social security and veterans' affairs system. I could talk for some time on many aspects of the legislation, but it is important, as previous speakers have done to a degree, to put this Bill in the context of the Budget and to put the Budget in context of the economic environment in which this Government has found itself over the last year or so. Basically it is an economic environment in which the prices Australia receives for its export products have fallen dramatically in the last 12 months and indeed overall over the past five years, many by as much as 20 to 30 per cent. In that context the Government brought down a responsible Budget which has kept spending to the minimum in seeking to reduce the Budget deficit and government demands for finance in the market, and to provide scope for the private sector to benefit from the new value of the dollar and improve employment and export opportunities. It is a responsible Budget which, because of the dramatic fall in the prices we have been receiving for our traditional exports-wheat, wool, iron ore, alumina and so on-has had to be tough, with a deficit of under $4 billion, and to keep real spending to zero. That is the background to the Budget and this Bill. In that setting it was incumbent on the Government to keep spending increases to a minimum in every area of government activity and to show the necessary fiscal discipline.

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of social security and veterans' affairs, it is fair to say that the Government took every opportunity to provide assistance to those most in need. This Bill contains several examples of that attitude, but the Government also had to make clear that some of the sacrifices had to be shared by other members of the community. The deferment of the six-monthly indexation of pensions by six weeks is part of this legislation. It is important to emphasise that this Government is not discounting pension increases. We would not do that because a discount to a pension increase tends to become locked into the system. Pensioners would always be struggling to catch up to their previous relative spending position.

In this legislation we are simply deferring the normal six-monthly consumer price index increase. Pensioners will still get the full CPI increase; it is just that they will receive it a little later than they might have expected. As the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) said, in circumstances where this Government has been asking ordinary wage earners to accept discounts of 2 per cent or more in their pay packets-and many wage earners in Australia are only on moderate incomes; some 80 per cent are below average weekly earnings and that is a statistic that we should always keep in mind-it is only fair that other people in the community should also be asked to accept some of the burdens that have been necessary in the introduction of this Budget and in this legislation.

This legislation provides also for a major crackdown on social security fraud. That is fundamental to the whole philosophy of this Budget. If economic conditions are tight, if there is not a bottomless pit of money from which to give handouts to community groups, it is absolutely crucial that the Budget revenue that is available is directed to the people who need it most and that money is not wasted on people who are able to cheat, defraud or in other ways manipulate the social security system. During the period of this Government, particularly since 1984, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has made very positive efforts to weed out those blatant cases of fraud in the system. This Budget continues that approach. It is not an approach which will in any way affect ordinary honest people who make up the bulk of beneficiaries in the social security area. However, in this legislation we want to ensure that people who are wrongfully manipulating the system for their own ends are no longer able to do so. For that reason, this legislation provides a series of measures which will limit the possibilities for abuse of the social security system. When one puts the pretty well thought out program embodied in this legislation in the context of what we have already done and what we envisage and have announced we will do in the future in terms of the Australia Card, one sees a very widespread Government program to eliminate social security fraud. It is probably worth saying that, for every $100m that can be saved from those who have been cheating the system, on average another 20,000 pensioners will be able to receive a full pension. That is the sort of dimension of the changes we are discussing.

This Budget is not all about cutbacks in the social security area. That is certainly part of it because this is a tough Budget and we believe that everyone in the community should contribute to the sacrifices that are necessary. We have gone to enormous lengths in this Budget to ensure that those most in need in our community are best protected from the reductions that have had to occur in Government spending. There are also some very positive social security expenditure aspects in this Budget. It provides assistance to the most needy in our community, particularly low income families with children and handicapped people. Some of the increases that will take effect from November this year include an increase of $1 a week to $17 a week in the allowance paid for children of pensioners and beneficiaries. That is not an enormous increase, but it means that in the 3 1/2 years we have been in government we have been able to increase that benefit by a massive 70 per cent-from $10 to $17. When inflation has been only of the order of 25 per cent over that period, that is a considerable real increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent result.

—Yes, it is an excellent result. We are also increasing the handicapped child's allowance by $7 a month to $92 a month. Again, that is a very commendable achievement in a difficult Budget. We are increasing the orphan's pension by $4.30 to $60 a month. We are also increasing the rate of family income supplement by $1 a week to $17 a week. All those measures build on the considerable achievements of this Government in the social security area. By Christmas this year the standard weekly pension or benefit will be 37 1/2 per cent higher than it was when we came to office in March 1983. That is considerably more than the rate of inflation and it compares with the real decline in social security spending and benefits which occurred in the Fraser-Howard years. By Christmas this year the benefit to single adult unemployed people will have increased by 54 per cent. The additional pension or benefit for each child and the family income supplement will have increased by 70 per cent over the past 3 1/2 years. More importantly perhaps, the mothers and guardians allowance will have doubled. Those are enormous achievements against a background of seven years of savage cutbacks by the Fraser Government. We have increased spending and allowances in the area of rent assistance by 50 per cent during the past 3 1/2 years, and again that is well above the rate of inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: When the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the shadow Minister for Social Security, suggested in this debate that this Government had been reducing its commitment to those in need in the community and cutting back on social security and welfare, he really was talking nonsense. If he wants to say that we have cut back on social security fraud, that we have taken pensions away from people who have been claiming them dishonestly, he is right. But if he says we are reducing the income levels of the people who are most in need in this community, he is totally wrong and he knows it. The fact is that we have acted in areas of need in our community, particularly for low income families with children which depend on the family income supplement. Not only did we put the family income supplement into place in 1983, but we have also increased it by a massive 70 per cent in 3 1/2 years. That means that someone in my electorate who is working in a textile factory for $14,000 a year and supporting three children can now receive $51 a week tax free assistance from the Government because of programs that we have introduced. That is not because of anything that Opposition members did when they were in government. They were hell-bent on screwing down poor people; that was their policy. We have provided genuine assistance to people in need, and that has been the hallmark of our Government.

I turn to a few of the points that have been raised in this debate by the Opposition. Let us look at what the Opposition promises for the future and particularly at what it did in the past-the Fraser-Howard legacy. It muddled its way through seven years of government. There is no question that it bungled the economy, botched the job market and systematically destroyed any income support mechanisms available for Australian families. In a sense that is what this legislation is all about-it is about trying to improve the living standards of Australians in need.

Let us look at some of the things that the Fraser-Howard Government left us with when we came to office. It destroyed job opportunities. When the Fraser Government came to power in 1975 there were 300,000 registered unemployed. When it handed over to us in March 1983 there were 635,000 Australians without jobs. What a remarkable achievement, in seven years. It doubled the number of people on benefits. If there is one way to alleviate poverty in our community it is to provide job opportunities for people. This Government has a record second to none in this area, not only historically in this country, but also in any international comparison that the Opposition cares to make. We have created 707,000 new jobs in 3 1/2 years-the best performance of any country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. It stands in pretty stark contrast to the pathetic performance of the Opposition. It threw 635,000 people on to the dole.

What did the Opposition do for families in the health system? Opposition members always say in this House that they support families. I have never heard such much claptrap. The Opposition had a health scheme which made a family with an income of $15,000 pay $700 a year for health insurance. Under our Government that same family pays nothing and has guaranteed access to public hospital and medical care. That was the Opposition's health system, and if it gets back into government it will do the same thing again. It will let the wealthy people off the hook and screw the poor people.

What were the Opposition's tax achievements? Members of the Opposition have talked today about fringe benefits tax, tax cuts and that sort of rubbish. The greatest achievement of the Opposition was the $4 billion worth of tax avoidance and the 28 memos that went to the Opposition's then Treasurer, who is now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). There were 28 memos from the Commissioner of Taxation saying: `For goodness sake, crack down on tax avoidance. This is the biggest rort that has ever been around. Ordinary honest taxpayers are picking up the bill for people cheating the system'. What did the Opposition do in the seven years it was in government? Did it take one single step? It did take one step, just before the 1983 election, but it was a little too late, because $3.5 billion had slipped through the system, never to be recovered. There was a massive transfer of wealth, and it was the poor old pay as you earn taxpayers who picked up the bill. That is what happened when the Opposition was in government.

Opposition members have stood up proudly today and made some comments about social security. When we look at what the Opposition did for families and children, its record was absolutely deplorable. It slashed the additional pension for children in needy families by 34.7 per cent in its seven years in government. If we look at the record of the Opposition's commitment to mothers looking after their families, the Opposition cut funding to them by 34.7 per cent in real terms. The fact is that when the Opposition came to government pensions were at nearly 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and the Opposition let them drop to 22 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about it?

—What have we done? We have increased pensions to nearly 24 per cent, and by the time of the next election they will be at 25 per cent. When Whitlam left office in 1975 pensions were at 24.7 per cent; when he came to government they were 21 per cent. Only one party in Australia looks after the needs of people on social security and those in need-the Australian Labor Party. That is the sort of legacy that was left to this Government when we won the election so overwhelmingly in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth looking at what this Opposition might do in the social security area, because that is what this legislation is all about, if it ever had the opportunity to get back into government. The key to what the Opposition would do is its commitment to the redistribution of wealth. I am not talking about weirdly radical programs; I am talking about a fair deal, a fair go, for ordinary Australians. The Opposition's concept of a fair go-the only solid commitments it has made if it is ever re-elected to government-is to abolish the fringe benefits tax lock, stock and barrel, at a cost of $700m; abolish the capital gains tax; and abolish taxation on lump sum superannuation. Members of the Opposition have made some references today to the fact that they would like to see deductibility for free lunches brought back. If we threw that in, that would cost about $1.2 billion. Where would the money come from to finance that? It would come from the ordinary PAYE taxpayers or through lower government outlays. The Opposition has made this commitment-I do not know whether it intends to keep it-to freeze real spending, but it knows that it will have ongoing commitments to fund these tax rorts which it has said it will reintroduce and commitments to education, roads funding and defence spending. If the Opposition wanted to keep real spending to zero, the people who would pay are the people on social security benefits. They are the facts of the matter and the Opposition knows it.

Opposition members have talked about needy families. I have never heard so much hypocritical claptrap. Let us see what a few prominent Liberals have said about the cuts they would make in social security spending. In the middle of last year the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Valder, advocated huge cuts on the Westpac video which he distributed so well around Australia. The same John Valder thinks that politicians on $45,000 a year ought to get massive pay rises. The shadow Minister for Social Security, who spoke in this debate, has come out strongly in the Press in favour of some type of compulsory work for single parents. Let me put on the record that there is no way I will support any scheme, as he apparently does, where mothers with four- or six-week-old children can be put out into the work force to work for 40 or 50 hours a week for an income below the poverty line. If mothers with children of that age want an option, they ought to be able to have the option of looking after their children. The shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown), said on the public record that if the Opposition ever gets back into power he will simply abolish unemployment benefits for the long term unemployed. That is a marvellous policy, is it not? What would he do with people who have worked their backsides off for 18 months trying to get a job but cannot get one-people who have families, houses and mortgages? He simply says that he will cut their income support. For goodness sake, what will they live on? What a stupid policy.

Another prominent Liberal, Andrew Hay of the New Right, has called for the total abolition of family allowances. If anyone listening to this broadcast today depends upon the $1.4 billion of family allowances this Government pays out, I hope they will realise how strong the push is in the Liberal Party to totally eliminate family allowances. That is what Andrew Hay wants. To top it off, the Leader of the Opposition was reported in the Melbourne Herald in November 1985 as confirming that if the Liberal Party got into power he would cut the dole and cut benefits to supporting parents. He said that the Liberal-National Party would not shirk the opportunity to reduce both benefits. That is a bit different from the approach we have taken. Mr Howard has said that he will make real cuts, money cuts, to unemployment benefits and supporting parents' benefits. I totally reject that line. We have done the right thing in a difficult Budget setting. This legislation is fair. I must say, from going around to pensioners and senior citizens centres, that this legislation is well supported.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the question of veterans' affairs. At the outset I remind the House and the people of Australia that this Government or any government in power owes a great debt to not only the people who served their country in time of war but also, more particularly in relation to this Bill, those who have been widowed as a result of war. That the Defence Force retirement and death benefits contract has been broken in recent weeks by this Government, with the 2 per cent discounting of pensions to people in receipt of DFRDB, is an absolute disgrace. Such a benefit is not to be likened to a social security pension. It is a contract between those people and government, established over many years. Many of the people who have paid into the DFRDB did so at considerable personal expense, going without many things in the latter years of their service to ensure that they would get that pension. It is a contract between the Government and those people. They are seeing 2 per cent of it being taken away. It is not a delay. They will never recover the 2 per cent which is being taken away because future consumer price index increases will be worked out on a smaller base. It is a disgrace that the Government seeks to pick on those people.

In this legislation we are seeing the freezing of social security pensions for war widows at $60 a week. Also a disgrace was that proposal, which has since been reversed, that if the pension were reduced below $60 a week it would never get back to the upper limit. One is hard pressed to find out why, if the income were subsequently reduced, the pension could not go back to the maximum limit. Certainly when I made inquiries of the Department in relation to that matter it was at a loss to understand why. I am very pleased to see that the situation has been restored. One may wonder why war widows are in a special category. We have war widows because their husbands died either in war or because of war. They are the ones who battled through those lonely years, raised families and worked for a living. It is the country that asked for the sacrifice of their husbands; they are the ones who have been left behind. We pay them the same sorts of benefits that we would have paid to their husbands if they had been disabled in a time of war. They are a special category. This prospect of taking them from the responsibility of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and away from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and putting them with the general population is a mean and despicable trick. As the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) has quite rightly pointed out, the benefits that are going to our veterans and their widows will decrease in the coming years. In this country we can afford to be generous to those people who have served their country and to the dependants whom they have left behind. The amount is not escalating; it is decreasing. Whatever government is in power we should be seen to be generous to those people.

They are some aspects of this Bill which are to be welcomed. It is a pity that I do not have time to cover the tightening up in some of the social security areas because they are very important. Generally speaking, it is an anti- pensioner Bill, an anti-veteran Bill and an anti-war widow Bill. We have to try to get some balance into the economic sacrifices that are being made in this country and not let some people take enormous benefits while others, such as pensioners and war widows, are being seen by everyone, not least the people concerned, as being highly discriminated against. I warmly support the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Richmond.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill which is before the House. This Bill gives effect to the decisions in the Budget relating to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs portfolios. I digress from my prepared speech to refer to the comments made by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) in which he stated that tax evasion was dead when this Government came to office in 1983. All I can say to the honourable member is that that is a joke. Unfortunately, it is a very sick joke because the economy of this country was in a very bad state due to the tax evasion practices that were manifold when we came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the Opposition's contribution to this debate illustrates the poverty of its present policies-policies of negativism, policies which would give to the haves and take away from the have-nots. If Opposition members want to regain the treasury bench-and it will certainly take them a long time-they will have to improve their game and be more honest with the elector- ate in respect of the assets test, the fringe benefits tax and tax evasion generally. The public remembers the lack of consistent policies of the Opposition when it was in power between 1975 and 1983.

As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) indicated in his second reading speech, many of these amendments have been brought in as a consequence of the current international economic conditions which have led to significant reductions in Australia's national income. A government is elected to govern. This means that from time to time hard decisions have to be made. This Government has had to face the challenge created by 30 years of mismanagement of the country's economy by those sitting opposite. Cutting $500m in the forward estimates of social security is neither an easy nor an enviable task, yet this restraint has been achieved with no discounting of index rises in pensions and benefits, as was mentioned in the excellent speech by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). Future six-monthly indexation increases to pensioners and beneficiaries will continue to be paid in full, but there will be a deferral for six weeks. Additionally, the measures implemented last year to reduce poverty traps in the social security system will be delayed until July 1987. These are the only changes to the general pensions and benefits area.

Whilst no pensioner or beneficiary likes having his or her indexation increase deferred for six weeks, most recognise that this is preferable to the other options of cutting out or discounting the indexation increases. There is genuine concern in the community about the delay. I do not deny that. Recently a senior citizen said to me: `We have all been through a depression and the Second World War and know that there are times when we have to tighten our belts. We are prepared to do this if other sections of the community are prepared to do the same'. I hope those opposite who are so keen to throw out the fringe benefits tax will mark the words of the senior citizen, for his words reflect the feeling of many people in the community towards the fringe benefits tax.

As a further cost saving measure, family allowances in respect of student children between 16 and 18 years of age will be income tested. Families with household incomes over $39,000 will not be eligible for family allowances for such children. This measure is in line with the Government's commitment to target welfare payments to the most needy in society. Family allowances currently provide between $5.25 and $10.50 a week per child. It is estimated that family allowances will increase by 1.6 per cent the disposable income of a single income family with one child receiving average weekly earnings in 1985-86. In other words, single income married couples with one child receiving average weekly earnings have 1.6 per cent more income to spend than similar couples without children. I make this point because this increase in disposable income illustrates the benefits of family allowance for those on average and low incomes.

In a situation where financial restraint has to be exercised, the Government's decision to target welfare payments to the most needy is most understandable. Yet there is no doubt that the amount of assistance provided to families with children has declined in Australia. The real value of the family allowance has declined by almost 30 per cent since its introduction in 1976-77. Unfortunately, the decline in the real value of family allowances has led to a situation where the proportion of gross income paid in income tax by families with children has increased by much more than that paid by families without children. This makes very timely the decision of the Minister for Social Security in December 1985 to commission the social security review.

One of the three major subject areas of that review is assistance to families with children. I, like many members from both sides of this House, look forward to seeing the final report of that review. I understand that the review will address, among other matters, the issue as to whether family assistance is best delivered on the outlay side of the Budget through cash transfers, or on the revenue side, through tax forgone.

There are a number of positive steps taken in this Bill which should be recorded. The additional pension or benefit applicable in respect of a dependent child of a pensioner or beneficiary will be increased by $1 per week to $17 per week as from 1 November 1987. This will mean a corresponding increase in the rate of family income supplement in respect of an eligible child to $17 per week as from 1 November 1987. The rate of double orphan's pension will be increased by $4.30 per month to $60 per month as from November 1986. Additionally, the rate of handicapped child's allowance will be increased by $7 per month to $92 per month as from November 1986. The rent threshold applicable before a person paying private rent can qualify for rent assistance will be increased from $10 per week to $15 per week as from 13 December 1986.

Clause 34 of the Bill, which amends section 107 of the principal Act, provides the qualification criteria for unemployment benefit. In effect, the amendments seek to tighten up eligibility for the benefit. It is interesting to turn to the 1983-84 annual report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich. On page 57 he showed that he understood the dilemma facing the Department of Social Security. He stated:

Generally the needs of the client beneficiary are such that the benefit or pension should be paid speedily. The primary function of the Department is that of a welfare organisation administering benefits as expeditiously as possible to its many client beneficiaries. This task requires sensitivity and understanding and cannot easily be reconciled with the Department's concurrent function of monitoring and investigating the payment of benefits and pensions so as to minimise the overall incidence of overpayment.

It is amazing, in view of the millions of cheques issued by the Department to the large number of beneficiaries, that the number of social security frauds is so small. I will give some figures a bit later. The Department has taken a number of actions since the Redlich report, taking note of the criticisms contained in that report. Numerous steps have been taken to deal with the detection and recovery of overpayments. The Minister for Social Security announced a number of them in the House in February this year. They include increased effectiveness in dealing with existing debt, measures designed to prevent future overpayments, and declaration of the three- month amnesty which occurred between March and May 1986. Pensioner clients are now being contacted twice yearly to remind them of their responsibility to advise the Department of changes in their circumstances. This addresses concern about the incidence of overpayments which arise in this area. The recent Budget initiative requiring sole parent clients personally and regularly to lodge a statement of circumstances will also reduce the number of cases in this category.

Direct credit is now the main means of payment of pensions, benefits or allowances. There is thus a greatly reduced scope for clients to claim improperly replacement cheques, as they were doing, or for third parties to steal and negotiate social security cheques. Cases of improper payment requiring police investigation, particularly involving schemes to defraud the Commonwealth, are referred to the Australian Federal Police as soon as it becomes apparent that such action is required. The work done on overpayments includes the drawing up of principles for the recovery of amounts outstanding in cases prosecuted for offences under the Social Security Act. It is good to see that there is now a full flow of information between the Department of Social Security and law enforcement agencies.

I mentioned earlier the millions of cheques issued by the Department. I am informed that, in 1985-86, 10.4 million cheques were issued. Of these, 19,825, with a total value of $3.3m, were fraudulently negotiated and were referred to the Australian Federal Police. As a result there were a number of prosecutions. As most honourable members know, prosecutions can be instituted under either the Social Security Act or the Crimes Act. There were 1,903 prosecutions under the Social Security Act, leading to 1,885 convictions, and 245 prosecutions under the Crimes Act, leading to 241 convictions. There were also 115 prosecutions under the Crimes Act for imposition-that is, where the client improperly negotiated both an original cheque and one which was issued to replace it after the client asserted that the original was never received. Convictions were obtained in 103 cases. I mention those figures because Mr Redlich in his earlier report expressed concern at what he alleged was the inactivity of the Department in those early days in recovering payment.

All honourable members would agree that no one can condone such fraud, and anything that can be done to reduce the number of frauds should be done. Three-quarters of social security frauds seem to come within the category of failure to notify change of circumstances. Two measures in this Bill aim to reduce such frauds. The first is that as from 1 November 1986 unemployment beneficiaries will have to be registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service in order to qualify for benefit, and the second is that as from that same date unemployment beneficiaries will have to lodge a current income statement and application for the continuation of benefit in person. This Bill recognises that there are occasions when a person fails to register because of circumstances beyond that person's control. A new sub-section in the Act will provide a power to disregard a person's failure to register.

I realise time is moving on but I do want to repeat what I said earlier: This Bill will cut some $500m from the social security budget. It is not a Bill that any Minister for Social Security would willingly introduce, but this is a time when tough decisions have to be made. This Government is prepared to make those tough decisions, unlike the present Opposition which when it was in government baulked all the time at such tough decisions. I therefore support the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say just one word of reply to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard). He said that the Fraser Government baulked at taking tough decisions. If he meant by that that it baulked at yielding to the temptation to get tough on pensioners and the people to whom this Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill refers, I am proud of its decisions. This Bill encapsulates the most miserable aspects of the 1986 Budget and shows just how miserable a Labor government can be. The burden being placed on pensioners and social welfare beneficiaries through the measures contained in this legislation, and as outlined in the Budget, is disgraceful. Much pre-Budget publicity was given to the fact that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) was outraged that cuts of half a billion dollars had to be made in an area involving people in greatest need. So he should have been.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see that there are some back bench members of the Government who have made their views known over time. Notwithstanding party loyalty, there comes a time when an honourable member must say: `Enough. Why am I here if it is not to give voice to the weak and the virtually voiceless?'. Age pensioners have some voice and war widows have some voice, but there are others who are treated disgracefully through the actions of this Government and who are voiceless. It is our responsibility to ensure that their position is made clear.

The actions of this Government in the veterans' affairs area has been a matter of some controversy for some time. In relation to war widows, the actions of the Government in this Budget should, I think, give justification to the alarm that veterans' organisations have been expressing for some time about the end intentions of this Government towards veterans. Our World War II veterans are of course now reaching the age of retirement and death-probably, I think it is fair to say, premature death in many cases. Anybody who is involved in the Returned Services League will tell us that its numbers are declining rapidly and significantly due to the death of veterans. Many men are dying in their late 50s and early 60s, well below the average life expectancy of men in the Australian community.

When the Government made its decision to reduce payments to war widows, I suppose it thought it was only taking on the war widows, but I am sure there are many members of the Government who have had the experience of members of the RSL expressing concern to them about direction in this area on account of their wives. They expect to die before their wives and they are extremely anxious that their widows be properly looked after. Their alarm is well justified. The decision, as the Minister euphemistically put it in his second reading speech, to restructure benefits and eligibilities is a mean one indeed. Of course, the Government has made it in the knowledge that the number of war widows will grow considerably in the next few years. The Minister is a master of euphemism. He uses words which sound mild and on occasions even kind. The policies that those words describe are anything but mild or kind. The Minister said in his second reading speech, referring to the Budget restraint that was necessary:
This restraint was achieved with no discounting of indexed rises in pensions and benefits.

That is not absolutely true because there are some payments presented as increases that are not equal to the level of inflation. I hope time will permit me to come to that. The deferral of the indexed increase for pensioners is not an indexation, it is just not paying. This six-week deferral will cost pensioners very dearly. The document from the Australian Council of Social Service community sector briefing notes contains this statement including the figures that are accepted:

When Labor came to office in 1983 it promised to reduce the time taken to provide the indexation increase in pensions from five months or more to one month. Three years later, no progress has been made and now the delay is to be increased by a further six weeks.
I think the Minister would probably refer to that as reverse progress. That is as euphemistic as one can get about it. It also stated:

Because of the Government's failure to fulfil this promise, pensioners on average have lost $400 since 1983. This financial year a single pensioner will lose a further $50 when the November and May indexation increases are delayed by six weeks and a pensioner couple will lose a further $80.
Happy Christmas pensioners of Australia, from the Hawke Government!

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on them.

—Indeed, it is shameful, as the honourable member for Denison says. At the time of year when pensioners most need a few extra bob in their pockets, this Government will make sure that they do not get it. Of course, this compounds a previous miserable decision of this Government about the amount of extra income that a pensioner may receive without losing any benefits. I welcome the fact that a pensioner can now receive $40 a week extra income without losing the pension. It was ridiculous that the amount was $20 for so long. I freely admit that that happened under a Liberal government and that it was nonsensical. Of course, other benefits were increased at the same time.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, it is a bit of a mockery when this Government has taken away the ability of pensioners to average their income over the year. No Liberal government required that they earn $20 every week of the year; they were allowed to average their income. Now, a pensioner who wants to be entitled to that amount of $40 without loss of benefits will not be allowed to earn more than $40 a week if he wants to keep all of those benefits. Why on earth should it matter to a government whether they earn that extra money for two months or 12 months, if that is all they earn? I will tell honourable members why it matters. The reality is that fewer pensioners have been able to take advantage of this and therefore have a reduced income because they cannot earn money in ways that they previously did without loss of benefit. Of course, the real reason, the benefit to the Government, is that it reduces the amount of benefits over periods when pensioners are earning at a rate greater than $40 a week but the total does not exceed the allowable amount. The record of this Government as it relates to pensioners is a disgrace. The Government has now taken action to allow sportsmen and women and people involved in the arts to average their income. I agree with that; their earning capacity fluctuates. Why does it not allow that for the least advantaged people in our society? Why can it not be consistent? The only motive can be cost cutting.

Another issue on which I wish to spend a little time-time is limited for all of us today because of the guillotine-is the issue of poverty traps. I said in a speech earlier this week that I am one of those people who welcomed the poverty trap measures announced by the Minister for Social Security some time ago. I refer to his words in the second reading speech on the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill 1985 in October 1985:

The Government has been concerned for some time that Commonwealth programs can interact in a way that disadvantages the people they should help, by trapping them in poverty. It has been recognised that the most savage of these poverty traps occurs when tax and social security interact.

There is something a little more savage; it is the savagery of this Budget as it affects the most disadvantaged, most poverty stricken members of the Australian community. It is universally recognised that the poorest people in Australia are those families with dependent children whose income is social security. Social security recipients who have dependent children are the most disadvantaged, those most caught in poverty in our community. Not only has the Government deferred implementation of the poverty trap measures that it talked about 12 months ago and on which it brought in some legislation not only has it extended the wait to 20 months after announcement it has compounded the poverty trap by several measures in this wretched Bill. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
Additional pension or benefit applicable for a dependent child of a pensioner or beneficiary will be increased by $1 to $17 per week, in November 1986 . . .

That is an increase nearly 2 per cent below the anticipated inflation rate contained in the Budget. This measure comes from the Minister who said that there would be no discounting for pensioners. That sounds to me like discounting. The benefit linked to dependent children will not even keep pace with inflation. The Australian Council of Social Service had something to say about that too. In general terms in relation to the poverty trap it said:

The poverty trap initiatives that were to be introduced in November would have helped nearly half a million pensioners who are trying to provide for themselves and reduce their reliance on Government assistance. The loss for pensioners in this financial year will be much larger than the amount taxpayers will lose because of the delays in tax cuts. A sole parent pensioner with two children and who is paying high private rent will lose $26 per week or nearly $900 this year. The poverty trap measures were introduced as part of last year's tax reform package, along with the cuts in income tax rates. Taxpayers will suffer only a three months delay in their tax cuts, but pensioners are expected to wait eight months.
That is for those who are least able to afford it. It also states:
The so-called increases in additional payment for children of pensioners and beneficiaries, and in FIS-
that is, the family income supplement-

are not real increases at all, since they are less than the increase in inflation. As a consequence of these real cuts in payments for children, plus the other delays in pension increases and income test changes, it is pensioner and beneficiary families with children-the neediest group in the community-who will suffer the most in this Budget.

Now where are the fine words of Government speakers who say how proud they are of the Government for facing tough choices? Every time they are tempted to say that, I would like them to look at the increase in the appropriations this year for the Australian Bicentennial Authority. It runs to tens of millions of dollars. That may be rationalised on the ground that this financial year 1986-87 is close to the Bicentenary. I am one of those who have supported the fact that we should be proud of and celebrate the Bicentenary that 1988 represents. However, I am also one of those who are disquieted by the enormous role that government will play. If this is a genuine celebration by Australians, it should not be necessary for us to spend tens of millions of dollars on this show. If the Government were really serious about the need to pull in its belt, it would have looked a little more closely at that.

One program that I had an interest in-I do not want to divert too far off the track-involved migrant groups. The Government has cancelled that and the money has been put into some sort of bureaucratic thing, some foundation here in Canberra. Yet migrant groups in the community were raising money in order to have a structured and good participation. That has been the Government's attitude on that. The Government could look at it as something to trim back. But to cut back on a spectacular that the Government has created for itself for 1988 is apparently out of the question. The Government instead looks at how it can trim back on pensioners and how it can take money out of their pockets prior to Christmas. The Government trims back on the poorest; it trims back on social security recipients desperately trying to rear their children in a decent way. This attitude is further demonstrated by the Government's decisions in relation to educational allowances. ACOSS said:

ACOSS deplores the proposal announced in the budget that pensioners and beneficiaries will no longer be entitled to receive Tertiary Education Allowances. In the proposal, pensioners commencing studies in 1987 will only be eligible for a $15 per week allowance. This presumably is supposed to cover extra costs such as child care and transport. Compared to the current arrangements a single pensioner with two children in full-time education will be $23 per week worse off.

Pensioners will be that amount worse off on top of all the other amounts that they are worse off. Bear in mind that these people are not going into education for entertainment or edification; their motivation, honourable members can be sure, is to qualify themselves so that they can get out of their poverty traps, get off the pension, get into salaried employment and give their children a decent fighting chance for the future. It is very clear that when this Government made its decisions it did not put these people at a very high priority. As I said at the beginning of my speech, there are some people and organisations which can speak for them. There is ACOSS; there are such organisations as the Returned Services League of Australia, the War Widows Guild and the Association of Civilian Widows. But there are many who are voiceless and therefore, they feel, powerless. It is a particular disgrace to this Minister that he can continue in the Cabinet knowing the effects of this Budget on these people and having that on his conscience.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should resign.

—He should resign, as the honourable member for Denison said-and I wonder how long it will be before he does. On the other hand, given that this has happened, perhaps it is just as well that he is still there. Clearly there are a lot of unsympathetic people in Cabinet and in the Government and maybe his voice is needed. In the couple of minutes left to me I want to refer to another matter that I have raised a couple of times in debate and compare it with the things I have just said. I have raised twice in debate on the appropriations the matter of widows and supporting parent's benefit recipients having to front up to bureaucrats for interviews and explain themselves shortly after bereavement or loss of their spouse. I will not at this stage take up the point that the Minister made in his reply a day or so ago in relation to de jure widows. I say, however, that his explanation does not satisfy me. I think it is callous, heartless and inhumane. I just put it to the House that we have a very large number of people receiving widows' pensions or supporting parent's benefit. We will have a policy that requires new ones to report monthly for a period, and quarterly thereafter. I ask the Minister the cost of that.
—It is minor compared with the savings.

—The Government has another system whereby it sends out letters to pensioners asking whether their circumstances have changed. Why, in the name of humanity, can that not be the system for these people? In the name of economy, if the Government is really going to do this, and give the counselling it is talking about-counselling is another euphemism-how many public servants will it tie up? The Minister said that the cost was minor in terms of the savings. If the measure forces people off the pension, that is a saving. If it saves on fraud, that is good; that is a saving. It would be more to the point if the Government got a move on on this subject of child maintenance. Reports of inquiries have been hanging around for years. We will not get any action until next year on the real issue and it will not be these interviews that achieve any savings in that area. I doubt very much whether, if the Government does this, there will be any benefit in it other than for the additional members of the Public Service that the measure will require.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to take part in the debate today on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. This Bill provides the opportunity for Australians as a whole to gauge in the clearest, starkest terms the fundamentally different approach in the areas of veterans' affairs and social security between this Australian Labor Party Government and the conservative Opposition. It is true that this Bill, unfortunately, contains a number of harsh measures-measures that, if the Australian economy were not so severely afflicted by the international trading circumstances of today, we on this side of the House would never contemplate. But the circumstance in which this Bill comes before the House is such that this Government has repeatedly called for restraint with equity. This Government believes that in these harsh times, while our economy undergoes the fundamental changes that honourable members opposite for 30 of the last 34 years failed to bring about, every Australian must share some of the burden of that reformation of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen that right across the board in Government policy. There is now a broader tax net on business. Income that previously has gone untaxed can no longer go untaxed in harsh times. Business is being asked to pay more. Wage and salary earners are being asked to accept less, and further real wage cuts are built into the system. Social security recipients, as a result of these circumstances, are also being asked to shoulder some of the burden of the national reconstruction. But this Government believes that people such as pensioners should bear less of that burden than the rest of the community. This Government believes that those least able should have the least call on them for sacrifice in the national interest.

We can see that belief epitomised in this Bill, because one of the major changes to the Social Security Act contained in this Bill is the six weeks delay, or three-pay period delay, in the indexation of pensions. I want the House, and indeed the nation, to focus very clearly on this instance because it provides the contrast that I spoke of a few moments ago. It shows the contrast with the standard that we are asking of the rest of the community, those more able to afford the sacrifice we are asking of them. For the rest of the community, for wage and salary earners, we are seeking a 2 per cent real reduction in income through the wages system. We are not asking that of pensioners. Pensioners instead are being asked for a delay, a deferment of six weeks on each of the two indexation periods. The Government is not seeking to reduce their full entitlement in terms of the cost of living. Pensioners are not being asked what this Government is asking of the rest of Australia. I place on record in this House that I believe that is absolutely and thoroughly the most correct position to adopt.

This instance provides a second contrast; that is, a contrast with the record of those opposite when they were in government. It seems that this country, and particularly pensioners, have forgotten the 1979 pension freeze, when there was no six-week delay of pensioner benefits, no three-pay period delay of cost of living increases for the aged, the disabled and other pensioners; there was a 12-month pension freeze by honourable members opposite when they were in government. In 1979 the international trading circumstances which Australia faced were nowhere near as onerous, in that sense not nearly as tough, as they now are. Yet in that period the coalition asked pensioners to take a greater rather than a lesser burden compared to the rest of the community. I notice a few heads among the Opposition suddenly slumping downwards as I make that point. Opposition members have forgotten the pension freeze which they forced on the aged. Opposition members forget their dark, dismal record. We on this side will take every opportunity to remind the aged between now and 1988 of those facts. If that is not enough, what is the current rhetoric of Opposition members on social security matters? They want more cuts. They come into this House, led by the wets such as the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), and bleed all over the chamber saying how terrible it all is, but what is the Opposition leadership saying? The truth is that when the Liberal and National parties were in government they treated the aged like lepers and now in Opposition they are calling on the Labor Government to kick the aged and other pensioners like the proverbial cat.

Let us not forget what best encapsulates the Opposition's philosophy. I take, for instance, the President of the Liberal Party, Mr John Valder, and his immortal words on the Westpac tape when he said what a wonderful thing it was that the Government was cutting back social security and that he would rush to watch our Government take those steps to save the Liberals having to do those things in government. Extracts from the Carleton-Walsh Report on 1 August 1985 are even more stark. I quote from that program when Mr Valder said:

If you want to have smaller government you're going to have to reduce, you know, the biggest burden or certainly the fastest increasing component of Government spending by far has been social welfare over the last decade. So if you're really talking about reducing Government spending, it's all very well to say we'll privatise this and we'll do that and fiddle with that. That's all fiddling with the edges. If you're really going to make any big reduction in Government spending, I've got to say there is one area it's going to be done in and it would have to be done in and that's social welfare, and pity the Minister for Social Welfare who has to do that.

I wonder whether the shadow Treasurer and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who are now at the table, who rushed around during the last election campaign telling pensioners that their gold fillings were to be counted in the assets test, scaring them in a shameless manner, would like me to read that sentence again from Mr Valder's remarks:

If you're really going to make any big reduction in Government spending, I've got to say there is one area it's going to be done in and it would have to be done in and that's social welfare, and pity the Minister for Social Welfare who has to do that.

That is the President of the Party whose supporters sit opposite, come into this House and bleed about this Bill but slink around the community calling for more. There is a clear philosophical difference between us on this side and those opposite. It is black and white; it is stark. Opposition members want further reductions in social welfare spending; they want smaller government. They want these things at a time when we on this side have pulled the Budget deficit down as a percentage of gross domestic product from 5 per cent to 1.5 per cent this year, and they call for more! What this must inevitably mean is that those opposite have in their drawers a secret agenda, which will mean more cuts for pensioners and veterans' entitlements and which will mean that every social security recipient across the country would not be able to sleep peacefully at night in the unlikely event that the Opposition should gain government.

Where is the brave New Right rhetoric of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the shadow Treasurer on this subject? They do not have the courage to spell out where these cuts will be; they do not have the integrity to table their policies on where these cuts will be or what will be the bottom line expenditure. Instead, there is mock indignation and mock amendments. Pensioners and veterans should be very wary because those on the New Right whom the Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer rush not to repudiate but to embrace-people like Brian Buckley and Andrew Hay, who set the agenda for those opposite, who pull the strings of the Leader of the Opposition-have done the talking on this topic. It is interesting to note that, in the recently published alternative budget by Brian Buckley, veterans' disability allowances were advocated for taxation. The agenda of the New Right that now controls those opposite advocates the taxing of veterans' disability allowance; it advocates a devaluation discount of the pension sector-a move that we on this side rejected. I am proud to say that I played my part in that. The pensioners in my area came to me and said: `We do not mind sharing some of the burden of the economic reconstruction, but we object to a discount, a pension freeze like the Liberals gave us'. That was rejected by us on this side.

Despite these cuts and what is advocated by those opposite, the 1986 Budget was not devoid of help for those less well off in our society and this social security legislation contains a number of favourable provisions: The level of rent assistance for a person eligible will increase by $5 to $15 a week; the additional pension or benefit applicable for a dependent child of a pensioner will increase to $17 per week; the rate of double orphan's pension will be increased by $4.30 to $60 per month; the handicapped child allowance will increase by $7 to $92 per month; and the mobility allowance will increase by $1 to $11 a week. That can be set against a record, of which this Government can be rightfully proud, in social security and veterans' affairs. It is this Government, not those opposite, which has not retreated from its commitment to raise pensions to a decent level. During the coalition's period of office pensions fell from 24 per cent of average weekly earnings to 22.7 per cent in March 1983. In May 1986 pension increases lifted that figure to 24 per cent of average weekly earnings, and the December increase will take the pension further along the path to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

Most significantly, the Australian Labor Party has an excellent record in community services for the aged, which is a noteworthy contribution to the welfare of the aged. Since March 1983 in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio under this Government spending has risen by 65 per cent, yet the honourable member for Moncrieff and the rest of the wets in the Opposition bleed all over the green leather benches in this chamber and say what terrible things the Government has done to veterans. I remind them that since that date we have increased expenditure on veterans' affairs by 65 per cent. The veterans' community has not forgotten that, either. In amending the Veterans' Entitlements Act the Bill seeks to correct machinery problems that have arisen since the inception of the Act four months ago. One of my constituents, a Mrs Doyle, had a problem in that she was awarded a settlement but, because of technical problems in the legislation, was unable to claim it. One of the amendments in this Bill will correct that problem. Amendments to the Act will now mean that the sum that was awarded and is owed to Mrs Doyle will now be able to be paid to her.

I highlight that case to show that when this Government sees a problem in legislation, it will make changes that benefit those in need. The Government is not afraid to introduce amendments where these are necessary. In Mrs Doyle's case, I am very pleased that a favourable outcome has been reached.

In conclusion, I make this point: Under the influence of the heady wine of the gallup polls of recent days, Opposition members are flushed with the thoughts of victory. But by 1988 that heady wine will bring about a gross hangover. The inhumane, harsh, Thatcher-like policies advocated by those opposite, which are in stark contrast to our own, will be flushed out by this Government and brought to the attention of every pensioner organisation and every Returned Services League sub-branch across this nation. At the next election the issues of veterans affairs and social security will be in black and white. The choice will be a government of compassion and realistic concern or an alternative government that believes in cutting for cutting's sake. I am pleased to support this Bill. I am pleased to support the record of this Government in the area of pensions, social security and veterans affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people of Australia have just been listening to the voice of the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), a member of a government which has shamefully betrayed one and a half million pensioners and beneficiaries and 650,000 ex-service men and women, widows and their dependants. This Government, more than any government since Federation, has broken almost every promise it made to the poor and elderly of Australia, and in this shameful Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill it betrays them once again. This Government, which promised justice and equity to the pensioners, has decided that it will rob the pensioners of Australia of some very valuable dollars in the six weeks running up to Christmas.
—That is disgraceful.

That was the official government policy and the directive issued by the Department of Social Security. The head of the Department, the Director-General, was a very great Australian, Mr L. J. Daniels. if . . . she lacks a cause of action in the strict sense of that term-

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my reply by indicating my pleasure at the way in which the Opposition, through the Leader of the Opposition, was associated with the very warm welcome given to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. I believe that the visit by the Prime Minister has set the stage for the injection of a dramatic new vitality into the relations between our two countries. Of course, the opportunity for that has been established by a considerable amount of good work done on both sides, not least by the visits that have been paid to India by my two colleagues the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I can establish three or four major themes which emerged and which will be of benefit to us all. The first major theme on which we reached total agreement was that the Government of each country could act as a catalyst for mutually beneficial economic co-operation. This will have concrete expression over the next few months in these ways: Firstly, in trade talks designed to identify commercial opportunities; secondly, in official and industry discussions on possible collaboration in coal development; thirdly, in the implementation of the science agreement signed during the visit; fourthly, in resumed negotiations on a tax treaty; and fifthly, by high level official talks early next year covering the whole breadth of our economic relations. In all those specific ways the first major theme of increased economic co-operation should bear considerable fruit.

Secondly-in a sense this is complementary to the first point-I believe the visit by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi brought home to the business sectors of both countries that the significant economic growth and restructuring in Australia, together with the huge Indian market, provides in the view of both sides considerable potential to move beyond what tends to characterise our two-way trade-that is, basically raw materials and a few consumer goods. It is quite clear that Australian prospects in India, ranging from projects in telecommunications to shipbuilding and civil engineering, are very promising. The interest of the private sectors in both countries came through clearly at the very productive meeting held under the auspices of the Economic Planning Advisory Council in Sydney yesterday, where we witnessed the signing by Australian and Indian business representatives of an agreement to establish a joint business council. I understand that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has agreed to chair the first meeting of that joint business council in New Delhi.

Thirdly, I inform the honourable member that I assured Mr Gandhi that we recognise that trade is a two-way street. The current balance is very much in Australia's favour-about 2 1/2 : 1-and we undertook to do the things we can within Australia to identify more opportunities for Indian trade into Australia. The fourth area is also of outstanding importance. The Prime Minister and I had very friendly, candid, direct and constructive discussions on many international political issues. I think all members of the House would realise that that is important, given the considerable importance and status of India as a power in southern Asia and the Indian Ocean region, and its important position in the United Nations, the non-aligned movement and the Commonwealth. It is clear, as the honourable member will appreciate, that we do not on every specific issue see exactly eye to eye with India. Nevertheless, there are many issues on which we do and on which we will continue to co-operate, particularly the vital question of southern Africa.

All in all, I am pleased to say to the House that I am confident that the visit to this country of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, short as it was, was extremely productive and will set the stage for a new, deeper and much more constructive relationship in all the areas I have mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have lost my irresponsible Queensland colleague, I ask whether the Minister for Health can inform the House of the Government's new plans for the recurrent funding of the Royal Flying Doctor Service, taking into account particularly the situation in the remote parts of Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to explain the proposed new funding arrangements for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. I am particularly happy to dwell on the shabby treatment of the Royal Flying Doctor Service-one of the great institutions of this country-by the Queensland Government. As the honourable member for Leichhardt knows, because he is very interested in the provision of flying doctor services, at the moment the Flying Doctor Service is funded by the Commonwealth for between 35 per cent and 40 per cent of its operating costs in each State. The States then meet part of those operating costs, and the amounts contributed vary from State to State. The remainder of the operating costs have to be picked up by the Royal Flying Doctor Service itself. Some States are particularly generous. For instance, South Australia contributes almost 50 per cent for its share of costs. Western Australia contributes 40 per cent. The most miserly proportional contribution of any State is that of the State of Queensland, which in 1985-86 provided as a proportion of the cost only 23 per cent. No other State in this country provided a more niggardly amount for operating costs than the Queensland Government. The result, of course, is that in Queensland the Flying Doctor Service has a very big bill to pick up itself-nearly $1 1/4m last year. The result is that it is now $183,000 in arrears in its operating costs.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth and the States have a joint working party which has come up with a proposal that the Commonwealth increase its funding to 45 per cent operating costs to all States on condition that the States meet that to the same extent-that is, that they provide 45 per cent, leaving the Royal Flying Doctor Service to find the remaining 10 per cent of the operating costs. At a meeting of the Australian Health Ministers advisory council earlier this month every State but Queensland accepted that new funding arrangement. The Federal Government is prepared to increase its contribution to 45 per cent of operating costs if the States meet that on a dollar for dollar basis, and the only State which has refused that offer is Queensland.

I would point out that the Royal Flying Doctor Service provides, particularly for Queensland, an essential and excellent service. Last year some 23,000 patients in the outback areas of Queensland, people living in remote towns, cattle stations, mining camps, or Aboriginal and Islander reserves, benefited from the services provided in Queensland by the Royal Flying Doctor Service. If Queensland will not come to the party and will not, like the other States, match the Commonwealth's contribution, it is clear that services may well have to be cut in Queensland because of the problems facing the Royal Flying Doctor Service in that State. I am not surprised that the Queensland Minister for Health has forgotten the country origins of the National Party. He quickly forgot the Party under whose banner he was elected at the last election. But I have written to Mr Austin reminding him of his duties to the country people of Queensland and asking the Queensland Government to reconsider its refusal to participate in the new arrangements.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment been drawn to the outrageous moves by the Opposition to disallow the plan of management for Kakadu National Park? Does the Minister intend to proceed with the Kakadu plan of management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today Senator Stan Collard, the Opposition spokesman on the environment-

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members-Who?

TALK.START.PARA: —Silent Stan Collard from Queensland. He has moved to disallow the Kakadu plan of management. Quite clearly the object of the exercise is for one reason only, that is, to allow mining in stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park. Let us also understand very clearly, despite protestations to the contrary, that this issue is about uranium mining. The Bureau of Mineral Resources has indicated that 90 per cent of prospectivity for minerals in stages 1 and 2 is for uranium and only 10 per cent for gold and platinum. The reverse is true in proposed stage 3. Over recent weeks Australians have been subjected to a massive media and political campaign to create a climate to permit mining in Kakadu National Park. We have seen articles in the Bulletin and in other papers, letters to the editors of the major dailies, statements by mining magnates such as Geopeko and the ranting statements of the honourable member for the Northern Territory. This softening up process is to prepare Australians for the Swiss-cheesing of Kakadu National Park. In a bizarre article in the Bulletin John Stackhouse commenced by stating `Kakadu is undoubtedly a national treasure. Its beauty is beyond compare' and proceeded to urge that it be mined.

ANSWER.PARA: Two specious arguments are being pushed by those who wish to see mining in Kakadu National Park. The first is that billions of dollars are being lost to Australia's export income by being locked up. Nothing can be further from the truth. First of all, let me remind members of what I said earlier: 90 per cent of prospectivity in stages 1 and 2 is for uranium. Judging by the way the pro-miners describe it, one would believe that the world was beating down our door to get uranium. There are two major sources of uranium in Australia, Ranger and Nabarlek, and one of the world's largest uranium mines, Roxby Downs, is still to come on stream. If supplies are required they can easily be acquired from those sources. Let us not forget that the Fraser Government did not permit the mining of the Jabiluka and Koongarra in the same region to come on stream because they feared the flooding of the world market with uranium. It planned sequential development to ensure that this would not occur. No attempt was made until 1983 to allow either mine to proceed. So let us have no more of this nonsense that billions of dollars are being locked up and that this is stopping Australia from solving its balance of payments problems.

The second argument is that massive mining of Kakadu is compatible with preserving the environment. All one has to do, we are told, is to put guards around the wetlands, the rock art, the flora and fauna and let the bulldozers have their heads. That shows a total ignorance of how ecosystems work. The simple fact is that there are very delicate wetlands in that area-and almost all the uranium prospectivity is in the wetlands. One would have to build a damn great dam around the area and mine in the middle of the wetlands. It is an outrageous proposal. Make no mistake, if the miners have their way-and they get support from the Liberal and National parties-Australia can gird itself for one of the biggest environmental battles in its history. It will make the Franklin saga look like a tea party. This Government will use every weapon in its power to ensure that Kakadu remains one of the world's great treasures.

—Can the Minister for Social Security confirm that a delegation from his Department has recently visited the United Kingdom for discussions with the United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security? Was one important element of those discussions the refusal by the United Kingdom Government to pay cost of living increases to United Kingdom pensioners who reside in Australia, in contrast with the procedure that it adopts for United Kingdom pensioners in the United Kingdom and in some other countries? Does the Government agree that United Kingdom pensioners in Australia are entitled to such indexation increases? What progress has been made in persuading the United Kingdom Government to live up to its responsibilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I announced in the Budget context, it has been decided to preclude United Kingdom working holiday makers from eligibility for Australian unemployment benefit. This matter was raised in September by officials from my Department with officials from the United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security. Agreement was reached at that level to preclude from payment of either country's unemployment benefit working holiday makers from the other country. It was also agreed that this should be done as quickly as possible by amending the reciprocal agreement with the United Kingdom. The officials are now considering a final form for a suitable amendment to that agreement, and I will advise the House further when that matter is finalised.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of non-indexation of United Kingdom pensions, this matter has long been a cause of serious concern for this and previous Australian Governments. The British Government has acknowledged the situation as inequitable, but says that it cannot afford to remedy it due to financial restraints. This response is certainly no longer satisfactory to the Australian Government, and all possible pressure is being brought to bear on Britain to accept full responsibility for its pensioners abroad. In this context the Prime Minister wrote to Mrs Thatcher in September expressing Australia's concern at the continuing imbalance in the present social security agreement. I have written in similar terms to the Minister of State for Social Security. Commonwealth and State Ministers have also been approached and asked to raise the matter of frozen British pensions in Australia with their United Kingdom counterparts at every possible opportunity.

The matter was, of course, raised during last month's talks with the United Kingdom officials and the suggestion was put forward of possible retaliatory action by Australia should Britain not unfreeze its pensions. As a similar situation applies to United Kingdom pensioners in Canada and New Zealand, we have had discussions with those countries also. This is an important issue of bilateral contention with the United Kingdom which the Government wishes to see resolved positively and urgently. In terms of the current negotiations for the renegotiation of the agreement between Australia and the United Kingdom, from our point of view this is a quite fundamental issue.
