TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government has recently completed a review of counter-terrorism capabilities in Australia and of the administrative and financial arrangements which support them. The Government initiated this review in December 1985. It was then some six years after the report of Mr Justice Hope had established the current arrangements and in the light of the upsurge of terrorism in Europe and the Middle East during 1984 and 1985 it was timely to review Australia's arrangements. The events of 1986 have confirmed the timeliness of the review.

SPEECH.PARA: The review was carried out by my Department in consultation with other appropriate departments. As part of the review, I made a visit in June to Italy, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Japan, where I had discussions on counter-terrorism with relevant Ministers, and with police and security agencies. I was also briefed in detail on airport security arrangements in those countries.
The Terrorist Threat to Australia

Australia is fortunate in not having disaffected domestic political or separatist groups who resort to terrorism, such as have many countries in western Europe. We are also geographically distant from the main centres of international terrorism. We have not entirely escaped terrorism. Major incidents in the past include:
The murder of the Turkish Consul-General and his bodyguard;
The bombings of the Israeli Consulate- General and the Hakoah Club;
The wounding of the Indian Defence Attache and the kidnapping of the Attache and his wife.

Nor should we be complacent about the future. It is important, however, that we not lose a sense of proportion and base our arrangements for counter-terrorism on worst-case scenarios; rather we need to make a sober and rational assessment of the threat. It is here that Australia's intelligence agencies and our links to international agencies play a vital role.

Even though Australians have been the innocent victims of incidents overseas and in this country, the present assessment is that there is currently no evidence to indicate that Australia is a chosen target of any international terrorist group. It needs to be borne in mind that Australia has close historical and political ties with a number of nations which are under high terrorist threat and which have substantial interests in this country. These interests may well be seen as attractive targets by terrorist groups.

The threat of terrorist attacks against targets in Australia is assessed by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation as low now and in the foreseeable future. This low threat is international in character, although we must face the possibility that some overseas terrorist groups may have a very few supporters in this country. Bombings and assassinations are the methods of attack currently preferred by terrorists and I am advised that this is likely to apply to any attacks which may be carried out in Australia.

The Government recognises that the source and the nature of the threat can change rapidly, but it accepts the advice that the current low level of threat against targets in Australia and the likely international emphasis on bombings and assassinations can generally be expected to persist for a period. The Government will therefore ensure that preventive and contingency measures against terrorism give the highest priority to these most likely forms of threat.
Conclusions of the Review

I now wish to inform the House of the findings of the review and the Government response. Acting on advice from the Secretaries' Committee on Intelligence and Security, the Government will not be publishing the report of the review. A complete copy has been made available to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and a version with only minor editing will be made available to the States. In general terms, the review concludes that an effective national counter-terrorist capability has been established in Australia. This follows the creation of the Standing Advisory Committee for Commonwealth-State Co-operation on Protection Against Violence known as SAC-PAV, in 1979.

The picture today is vastly different from 1979. There is an atmosphere of co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States that could not have been foreseen seven years ago. Through SAC-PAV, the Commonwealth has provided the States with compatible equipment and helped to develop among them similar levels of expertise. The relevant Commonwealth authorities can now interact with each State more easily, and are more likely to be invited to do so. The State Governments and police forces can also more readily interact. Extensive crisis management machinery has been developed that can be activated in response to a terrorist incident anywhere in Australia. A highly skilled and well-equipped counter-terrorism force has been established within the Australian Defence Force to respond, as a measure of last resort, to request to resolve terrorist incidents by force. Every State now possesses a capability to cope with siege-hostage incidents, at least those of relatively short-duration. All States have a raised capacity to deal with bombings.
Preventive Measures

The review emphasised that the single most important preventive measure against terrorism is the capability to produce timely and accurate intelligence. The Commonwealth's principal agency for gathering and evaluating security intelligence is ASIO. That organisation's particular role was, of course, thoroughly examined by the Recent Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies conducted by Mr Justice Hope.

Co-operation between intelligence and law enforcement agencies, both in Australia and internationally, is vital in the area of counter-terrorism. This was a point strongly emphasised to me by all concerned during my overseas visit. The review reported general satisfaction with co-operation between the agencies in Australia.

Relative to many other nations, Australia has a greater capacity to prevent known or suspected foreign terrorists from entering this country. The review emphasised the importance of the security-checking mechanisms now in place with several foreign security services which could provide information on the movement of terrorists in time to prevent their entry into this country. The Government accepts the importance of these mechanisms.

The review further recommended that current entry control procedures be maintained, including the necessity for visitors to Australia to obtain visas. These recommendations will be taken into account by the Government in any future examination of this issue. The review drew attention to the need to enhance the protection of Commonwealth explosives and weapons and to make a careful assessment of the threat posed by other sources of dangerous materials of potential use to terrorists. As a result of the review, action is being taken to upgrade our performance in this area.
Protective Measures

The protection of potential targets is a vital measure in any country's fight against terrorism. This is an area of change in the Commonwealth as a number of the former protective roles of the Australian Federal Police have passed to the Australian Protective Service. The Government sees the advantage to both the development of the AFP and to the performance of protective functions in this change. There are Commonwealth-State arrangements for the protection of holders of high office in Australia or dignitaries who may be visiting Australia.

The very considerable resources and the degree of co-ordination required have been recently demonstrated in the visit by the Indian Prime Minister. The forthcoming visit of the Pope will also be a major exercise. While this task must remain primarily the function of the particular state police forces, the review has pointed to the need for agreement on minimum standards of protection in response to different levels of threat. This will be pursued in the SAC-PAV forum.
Reactive Measures

Australia needs to be prepared to respond if preventive measures fail and a terrorist incident takes place. A major element of Australia's response to incidents of terrorism is a policy of no concessions, other than tactical ones, to terrorist demands. That policy has been considered and re-endorsed by the Government as a result of the review.

The review pointed to the need for some improvement in the information flow to Commonwealth Ministers during a terrorist incident to enable them to make any necessary policy decisions. This need has emerged during a number of Commonwealth-State joint exercises. The review also pointed to the need to plan and train for post-incident investigations and other actions which would form a major part of the response to a `hit and run' incident, such as an assassination or a bombing. If we are to improve the chance of apprehending offenders and hence reduce terrorism. The Commonwealth will be looking to the SAC-PAV to extend its exercise program to test arrangements for Australia's response to this wider range of incidents. There may be terrorist incidents arising overseas in which Australian interests would be heavily involved and in which Australia could be called upon to assist. The Government is examining the complex issues raised by such situations.
Aviation Security

It is clear from international experience that airports and aviation, particularly international aviation, are prime targets for terrorist attack. On my visit to Europe I was struck by the very particular attention being paid to high risk flights at major European airports. The flights of certain airlines and flights to and from certain destinations are given very special attention; otherwise more routine precautions prevail.

Fortunately, the terrorist threat to aviation in Australia is assessed as low. Our aviation security arrangements fully meet all of the International Civil Aviation Organisation standards. Nonetheless, it is important that we keep the security needs of our airports under constant review so that we can ensure that we are prepared to face any problem which may arise. In the light of the review's recommendations, bomb and weapon search procedures are being reviewed to ensure that these continue to be adequate for the prevailing circumstances. The current system of issuing passes to people for access to security areas of airports is also being looked at to see what strengthening might be desirable.

The Government is also concerned with the broader aspects of physical security measures at airports and is taking action to improve current arrangements. My Department and the Department of Aviation have established a joint task force on proposals to improve aviation security at all Australian airports. The difficult question of policing of airports was addressed in the review. At present, uniformed Australian Federal police are present at Australian airports. Their role in a terrorist incident would be one of containment until the arrival of State police. Inevitably, as a visible presence, they are called upon to undertake something of a community policing role, which properly belongs to State forces. There has been criticism of the numbers of AFP members at airports for counter-terrorism purposes. This criticism is not supported by the AFP on the basis of the present threat and current national planning for a counter-terrorist response. It is also worth mentioning that the AFP has other roles and often considerable resources at airports working in intelligence, drugs and other operations.

The review canvassed the options of a special airport branch of the AFP but favoured rather the transfer of the counter-terrorism protective function to the States. This was seen as better meeting any possible problems of two forces in one incident and offering greater flexibility should the threat increase. I will be discussing this possibility with the AFP, the Australian Federal Police Association and the States and will then bring forward a further submission to the Government.
Bombing Incidents

Bombings have been the most common type of terrorist incident in Australia and are expected to be the most likely form of such incidents in the future. While bombings are assessed as the major threat from terrorists, the Government is concerned that this should be reflected in the attention given to the subject by the SAC-PAV and in the allocation of money to the SAC-PAV by the Commonwealth. Provision has been made in 1986-87 to expend $350,000 on bomb disposal and related equipment. We are planning next year, 1987-88, to spend the entire SAC-PAV plant and equipment vote on equipment that will further enhance our anti-bombing capacity.

The review highlighted, among other things, the absence of SAC-PAV exercises aimed at testing bomb response capabilities. As a direct consequence of this finding, a bomb response seminar is to be held in Canberra on 5 November 1986. The seminar, to be attended by Australian and overseas experts in forensic science, counter-terrorism and explosives, will examine Australia's preparedness to respond to worldwide trends in the use of explosives by terrorists. In addition, the SAC-PAV has been asked to develop a bomb response strategy for the next three to five years with the emphasis on equipment, training and personnel requirements. This proposal will be discussed further by the bomb response seminar at the sixteenth meeting of the SAC-PAV in November 1986.
Financial Arrangements

Finally, there was an examination of the financial arrangements as between the Com- monwealth and States. Since 1980-81 the Commonwealth has spent about $10m on equipment, ammunition and training through SAC-PAV. Annual costs for counter-terrorism aspects of ASIO, the Defence Force, the AFP and my Department amount to about $30m. A variety of alternative options was considered, including a user pays principle, a fixed Commonwealth-State contribution ratio and a Commonwealth-only option. The mechanisms necessary to control the financial contributions made by the Commonwealth through the SAC-PAV towards the national capability was canvassed. The review concluded that the present financial guidelines, with some minor administrative adjustments, should be maintained. The Government accepts that recommendation and will continue to provide financial support through SAC-PAV within modified guidelines.
Conclusion

The Commonwealth will seek the continued co-operation of the States and the Northern Territory in putting into effect measures arising out of the review. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is writing to the Premiers and the Chief Minister following the review. The Government acknowledges the excellent level of co-operation which has already been achieved. Terrorism, by its very nature, recognises neither geographic nor political boundaries. Although the threat is currently assessed as low, there will be no reduction in our vigilance nor in the maintenance of the national capability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Terrorism is here to stay. The review which is now before the House, in the terms of the statement which has been made by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), is an important one. The Minister has pointed out that the present arrangements grew out of a review by Mr Justice Hope in 1979, and it was during the office of the Fraser Government that the present arrangements were established for State and Commonwealth co-operation on protection against violence.

SPEECH.PARA: Terrorism is a grave and growing problem for democracies. As the Special Minister has pointed out, terrorism by its very nature recognises neither geographical nor political boundaries. The democracies and their citizens are the most frequent targets for terrorism, and they are the most vulnerable. In large part, this is due to the nature and the openness of democratic systems. It is a very different matter when one has to deal with terrorists in a closed authoritarian system. That is very much easier; for us it is very much harder.

The Minister has called for a sober and rational assessment of the threat. I quite agree with that approach, but I believe we should not underestimate the threat nor should we underestimate the potential for the threat to develop quickly. It is not one of those matters that can be nicely evaluated. It can, and does, sometimes arise, as overseas experience demonstrates, very quickly and very wildly. Terrorism is, of course, a direct challenge to the democratic societies. It attacks our values. Terrorists refuse to recognise the rights of innocent people, such as the very simple right to life. State sponsored terrorism, such as that of Libya and other states, is used as a political tool and is designed to undermine other countries, particularly the democracies. Terrorism at all levels can provoke fear in political leaders and in others. As events in countries such as Italy all too tragically show, it causes men and women to live in everyday fear of their lives.

Combating organised terrorism represents a great challenge. The activities of terrorist groups are highly organised. Indeed, mobility and the openness of democratic societies facilitate their work. There is evidence of increased co-operation between terrorist groups of diverse political, ethnic and geographical backgrounds and intelligence exchanges between those groups. Another feature of political terrorism which has become all too obvious is the use of organised crime. It has been said that modern terrorists need plenty of money. Major international groups need budgets rivalling those of major business corporations. Money is the fuel of international terrorism. The high cost of terrorism has led to the direct involvement of terrorist groups in bank robbery, extortion, kidnapping and the drug trade-what the Drug Enforcement Agency of the United States of America calls `narco-terrorism'. Some picture of the involvement of terrorists in organised crime may be given briefly by a quote from one of the current parliamentary paper issues, `Briefings on International Terrorism', in which this instance is given:

In mid 1985 it was alleged that an Australian drug syndicate had purchased up to 10 tonnes of cannabis resin, worth an estimated A$40 million, from an unnamed terrorist organisation in the Middle East and imported it into Australia in March 1984. This allegation was followed by the arrest of over thirty members of the syndicate by the Australian Federal Police in mid August 1985. According to Dr Grant Wardlaw the terrorist group involved is probably a PLO splinter group operating out of the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon, where such groups are involved in growing and exporting hashish under Syrian protection. At the same time it was reported that five members of just such a PLO splinter group had been convicted by a British court on charges of smuggling drugs and buying guns with the proceeds. The forging of such links between narcotics traffickers and terrorists carries serious implications for the attempts by Western governments to achieve effective international controls over drug smuggling.

The report was provided to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in confidence. That confidence will be maintained without any qualification. As far as possible in this area bipartisanship should be observed. The very fact that the report is provided in confidence prevents the possibility of commenting on it. I raise with the Special Minister of State, as I raised informally with him before the House sat this afternoon, the possibility, as in the case of the report of Mr Justice Hope of 1979, of issuing an unclassified version of the report. I acknowledge there are difficulties in that course. It is a matter of judgment as to whether or not an unclassified version could be issued.

I should like to say something about preventive measures. The Special Minister has pointed out that timely and accurate intelligence is a single most important preventive measure. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation is the agency on which we rely so greatly for information concerning possible terrorist activities. The Opposition fully supports ASIO. I say in passing that it is a matter of concern that there should be such continued deep animosity to ASIO from sections of the Left in the Labour Party. This has led, unfortunately, to the surrender by the Government and the establishment of a parliamentary review, a sort of ambulatory body, to review ASIO, under certain rules of course, but opening the prospect of leaking vital information of an intelligence nature. One can only hope that ASIO's operations can continue with undiminished force and with undiminished efficiency. It is an essential organisation.

The Special Minister referred to bombing and assassination as the current preferred methods of attack. I agree that experience demonstrates that that is right. He will know that firearms and explosives are all too easily available in this country and that the legislation varies from State to State in respect of firearms. I think the same is the case in respect of explosives. I believe that the Australian Capital Territory is lagging behind New South Wales and Victoria in this field. The need for a co-operative and common approach between the States and the Commonwealth to control over firearms and explosives is all too obvious. I ask the Special Minister to take this matter up and to let us know as soon as he can what progress can be made in securing co-operation on the controls, on the sale and availability of explosives and firearms.

The Minister spoke in his statement of point of entry controls. These days point of entry controls are to be found predominantly at air services. Of course, our geographical isolation helps, but the security checking methods at airports are by no means what we need. Let us take, for example, the information retrieval systems which are available when one goes through Customs and Immigration controls. There is a problem. It looks very efficient, but it is public knowledge that there is a time lag of some three months or so between information on suspected terrorists, criminals or other undesirables being available and that information being programmed into the computer. Effectively, the Customs services are dealing with out of date information. That would be known all to well to those who might seek to evade those controls. We have visa controls in this country, and so we should. There is a 72-hour transit visa. I simply raise with the Minister the query as to whether or not there is any need to review that transit visa and as to what kinds of abuses may have taken place in respect of transit visas.

As we know, we have as well the entry of delegations to this country, such as the representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organisation. We all know the history of that organisation and, in particular, of some of the groups under the PLO umbrella which engage in terrorist actions of the most outrageous kind. I should be glad if the Minister would inform us at some stage, I know he cannot do so this afternoon, of the difficulties to be found in screening the kind of intelligence coming out of the Middle East that is available-I believe it is not good-and what we can do to improve our screening of individuals who may be members of so-called political or non-aligned delegations of organisations such as the PLO.

The Minister has spoken of aviation and airport security. A number of airlines, which have been the subject of terrorist attacks and hijacking fly into this country, such as British Airways, Trans World Airlines Pty Ltd and Air India. The potential danger should not be exaggerated, but there is obviously a need for strict security controls, far stricter than those that presently exist. The Minister in his statement has acknowledged this need. The present systems are too lax and too haphazard. The Auditor-General in his recent half-yearly report has said that passengers ordered to have passage checks could avoid them, that computer alerts identifying potentially dangerous passengers could be ignored and that the identity of aircraft crews was never checked. That is a hazardously sloppy state of affairs. What is to be done? Perhaps the Minister can come back at another time and tell us what has been done to overcome that kind of situation. Everyone knows the hit and miss nature of internal checks on internal flights. On the face of it they seem pointless since a terrorist would simply catch the next flight. Is further action necessary? Has the Minister got that matter under consideration? Will he come back to the House and tell us what needs to be done in that area? If he thinks nothing needs to be done, he can tell us that.

The Minister has referred to protective measures. He points out that the review favoured the transfer of counter-terrorism protective functions to the States. If that takes place it is essential for State forces to have the right calibre of personnel and high levels of training. Anti-terrorist actions, for example, the storming of an aircraft-the ultimate worst case seen-are high risk ventures. The highest level of training and aptitude is necessary. The difficulties of achieving such levels of training and aptitude outside of a specialised force, such as the Special Air Service are, it seems to me, all too obvious.

I understand that certain problems have been experienced with State police forces and the use that is made of State police forces of a counter-terrorist character or those who have counter-terrorist training for actions which have nothing to do with counter-terrorism. I cite a reported instance of the tactical squad of New South Wales being used for the purposes of recovering a 15- or 16-year-old boy whom the police were seeking. In the course of being pursued he was shot in the leg. Using that tactical squad seems somewhat of an over reaction. I ask: Can we get the levels of expertise, dedication and aptitude that are necessary from the police forces?

Mr Justice Hope in his 1979 report made some recommendations which are relevant to the use of the military forces. The military forces are the last recourse. He recommended the enactment of legislation amending the Defence Act in relation to the use of the Defence Force in civilian security operations. I believe that has not taken place and that action-that is, the explicit acceptance or rejection of Mr Justice Hope's recommendation-is long overdue. Perhaps again the Minister can come back to the House and tell us what the Government intends to do about Mr Justice Hope's recommendation on that matter.
I make one or two brief points in conclusion. First, let me quote from the public report of the United States Vice-President's Task Force on Terrorism of February 1986. The Vice-President said:
International co-operation is crucial to long-term deterrence to terrorism. It can be achieved through multi-lateral and bilateral agreements.

In fact, international agreement and co-operation is both crucial and difficult to achieve. It is essential that the democracies agree upon common measures and common approaches to dealing with international terrorism. For example, as a consequence of the hijacking of an Italian cruise ship there was an argument between the United States and Italy as to where the hijackers should be tried-whether they should be tried in Italy under one set of laws or in the United States under a different set of laws. The democracies ought to be able to organise these matters better. It seems to us perfectly absurd and dangerous that the democracies cannot agree on such fundamentally important questions.

Lastly, I pay tribute to all those in this country involved in counter-terrorism. The work is basic, it is demanding and it is sometimes highly dangerous, and we all know that if an event arises which requires people to risk their lives then they have to risk their lives. We look to them to do that as part of their everyday work. It is hard work, and all those involved should have the fullest support of every member of this House.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act as amended in 1983, and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their renumeration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;

That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa electorate respectfully showeth that:

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, not in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap can be terminated from 19 October 1986.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government support the introduction of additional television channels through the Multi Channel Service proposal submitted by North Queensland Television.
We oppose the aggregation option favoured by the Government as this will lead to a loss of local programming, community service involvement and local employment at NQTV.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government support the Multi Channel Service proposal submitted by North Queensland Television.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Justice, Equity and Redistribution of Wealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, hereby petition the Prime Minister as Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Government in Australia and humbly showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Give speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian Republic on or before 1st January 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor, Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian atomic energy establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W., or any site within Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights or within Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Lucas Heights Nuclear Reactor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That in the wake of the Chernobyl reactor disaster, no nuclear reactor can be considered entirely safe.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government close down the Lucas Heights reactors immediately and permanently, and that no new nuclear reactors be built within Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Secondary Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Western Australia call on the Commonwealth Government to reverse recent decisions which deny Secondary Allowances to Year 11 Students under the age of 16 years and make such allowances directly payable to students on attaining the age of 16.
This request is made on the basis that:
(i) Education benefits as part of income support benefits generally are a Commonwealth responsibility under the constitution.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain residents of the Northern Territory of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation recently passed by Parliament is unfair and will prejudice the current working conditions of all Territorians.

2. It will undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competitiveness of industry.
3. It will result in price increases.
4. It will force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments.
5. It endangers stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of Fringe Benefits.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take such action as is necessary to rescind the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1986.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully demand that the Federal Government take responsibility for existing and future funding of child care services and that such funding allocation be at such level to ensure the maintenance of quality child care. We further respectfully demand that proper planning of services occur and that the Federal Government enter into formalised agreements with State and Local Governments to achieve this result.

DEBATE.TITLE: CAPITAL GAINS AND FRINGE BENEFITS TAXES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The devastating effects that the Government's new taxes, especially the Capital Gains Tax and the Fringe Benefits Tax, are having on employment and business activity in rural Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government's policies and in particular its taxation policies are having a devastating impact on the viability of businesses, miners and farmers in rural Australia. I remind the Government that 80 per cent of Australia's export earnings come from the mining and farming industries. Only this week we have learnt that Australia is running a trade deficit equivalent to $17,000m annually. This staggering figure, greater than half our gross export earnings, is crippling country Australia. From these figures it is obvious that this country needs every export dollar it can earn and that the Government should be encouraging the rural sector instead of burdening it with a whole new welter of bureaucratic legislation and new taxes, as it has done since it came to office. Such socialist nonsense is crushing the incentive and economic lifeblood out of rural Australia. The Government must realise that, if the exporters of this country go under from the weight of these taxes, the whole of Australia goes under.

SPEECH.PARA: The list of new taxes that we have had to stomach is as long as the looks on the faces of present Government members will be after the next election. There has been the superannuation lump sum tax, the entertainment tax-there goes 11,000 jobs-the removal of negative gearing which is pushing rents sky high, the assets test on pensioners and the iniquitous capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax that we will repeal. There has been a whole host more. There has been the doubling of sales tax on wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shocking thing. It extracts another $47m out of the wine industry at the same time as the Government is spending $5m on a vine pull scheme. We have extra taxes on milk. We have extra taxes on fruit juices. We even have taxes on pony clubs, for heaven's sake. The National Farmers Federation has calculated that high analysis fertiliser prices will rise by $47 a tonne as a result of recent Budget decisions. The list goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the highest taxing, highest spending government in the history of this nation. The Government has become obsessed with tax. We might wonder what it does with all these taxes. We might ask what it could be spending it all on. This Government is throwing money around like confetti in a hurricane. The taxpayers of Australia would rise up in revolt if they could see where some of it is going. I have a 10-page list of Australia Council grants to left wing trade unions alone. It seems that almost every trade union in the country is funded at the taxpayers' expense to have a muralist in residence, an artist in residence, a lyricist in residence and a story teller in the community. It is unbelievable. When I show people this list, they just cannot believe it. There are grants of $10,000 here, $30,000 there. No amount is too high. There are grants to homosexual groups, communist groups-nothing is too radical for this Government to bankroll. There is one grant of several thousand dollars from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to hold a conference. Honourable members may well ask what for. It is for the National Network of Young Lesbians and Homosexual Men.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.
—It is disgraceful.
—How much?
—The amount is $5,000. Unfortunately all this has to be paid for from the extra taxes that have to be raised, which are causing enormous hardship and job losses in country areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look briefly at the assets test. In the town of Nyngan in my electorate there is an 89-year old ex-digger from the First World War and his 91-year-old wife. They retired a few years ago and moved into town to live out the remainder of their lives in what they thought would be peace and dignity. They borrowed against their life insurance policies to buy a modest house there. The son works on the farm and the income from the farm barely supports his family. Now, these ruthless tax gatherers have taken away this old couple's pension and the couple are bewildered and upset. You may well ask what they are living on. They are living on home care and Meals on Wheels. But, do not worry, Mr and Mrs Gibson from Nyngan; when we get rid of these mongrels from the Government benches, we will repeal this tax straight away.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The terminology used against other members was totally unparliamentary.
— The honourable member will withdraw the unparliamentary words.
—I meant no offence, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was simply referring to their breeding.
—Order! The honourable member should not compound the matter. The honourable member will withdraw.

—I withdraw. I have not yet mentioned the fuel tax. Despite promises to drop it, this Government has lifted its share of excise tax from $1.3 billion when it came to power to $5.5 billion. That is a 336 per cent increase. A whole town in my electorate has closed down because of the increased excise on diesel fuel. I refer to Fifield, where there was a magnesite mine. Diesel was used in their furnace. The mine could get no relief from those taxes. Seventy workers plus their families have been put out of business and Australia has an extra loss of export income.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the farmers in Australia? They are struggling under a debt of $8,000m. They are living on $70 a week. Not only are they paying high fuel prices and almost the highest interest rates that this country has ever seen; they are now to be burdened with a capital gains tax and a fringe benefits tax. The capital gains tax is calculated to pluck an extra $300m a year out of the community.
Discussion interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.45 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.
Mr Holding-I require that the question be put forthwith without debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CAPITAL GAINS AND FRINGE BENEFITS TAX

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fringe benefits tax will extract another $600m to $700m a year. Both of these taxes are hitting the mining and business industries also. The Executive Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council has said that 3,000 jobs have already been lost in some mining areas because of the fringe benefits tax and that another 3,000 jobs will go in the near future. So much for decentralisation and job creation! The capital gains tax is discouraging investment in industries of high risk that often give very low returns on capital investment. Of course, that erodes borrowing capacity. The possibility of a capital gain at the end of a working life is all that keeps some businesses going now. That has become their superannuation policy. If we take that away from many people, they will just leave.

SPEECH.PARA: The capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax are full of anomalies. Let us take the example of a son who has been given a low interest loan by his parents so that he can establish his own business or get a start on a farm. The parents will now have to pay fringe benefits tax on that low interest loan. It is almost unbelievable. The fringe benefits tax has become a bureaucrat's paradise. We have 139 pages of legislation from the Australian Taxation Office. We have 11 new tax rulings so far of 97 pages and there are still many more to come. There is one booklet of 56 pages, another booklet of 113 pages, several Press releases-and a video, for goodness sake. The situation with the capital gains tax is no better. We have a 155-page explanatory memorandum and 103 pages of legislation. The country is awash with paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Red tape.

—There is red tape everywhere. As I have said before, these taxes have created the three Ps in Australia-poverty, paper and public servants. I will read from a telegram I received today to show that it is not just the problem with the money that is being collected; it is the paperwork that goes with it. This telex is from a Mr R. P. Hansen, who states:

SPEECH.PARA: FBT quarterly liability took two days to calculate plus tedious and infuriating compilation of log books and additional accounting costs. All for a tax of $49.97. FBT onerous, wasteful and ludicrously inefficient, generating savage resentment among Australia's several million small business people. Have suspended all such benefits to employees with expected compensating decrease in productivity. Greatest unforeseen consequence will be net loss to Australia. I urge you and your colleagues to repeal this nonsense.

I say to Mr R. P. Hansen that we will do that. I turn now to mention the country shires. Of course, they have to pay fringe benefits tax. That alone will run into several thousand dollars. I am in the process of going through the shires, of which I have 13 in my electorate. The ratepayers in country areas are already very hard pressed. I am pleased to see the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) here. The roads in country areas are deteriorating and have been doing so over the past three or four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the money going?

—One wonders. If fringe benefits tax of several thousands of dollars is imposed on each shire, rates will have to go up to compensate for that alone, or else taxpayers will have to foot more in grants to the councils, or the roads will deteriorate even faster. They are the choices. So much of the fringe benefits tax is unclear. So much of it is confused. Some accountants who have approached me in my electorate are too frightened, too scared, to give rulings to their clients who ask them questions, for fear that the Tax Office will come down with another ruling in the future which will change the situation and thereby make the accountants liable to be sued. What a ridiculous situation we have got ourselves into. Look at the case of the Australian Taxation Office. Even the Tax Office itself has to pay fringe benefits tax. I guess that when we finally have the spectacle of some public servant in the Tax Office sitting down and writing a cheque to himself we will know that this country has truly gone mad. I guess the Tax Office collecting fringe benefits tax from itself is a bit like the economy drinking its own blood.

SPEECH.PARA: The mining industry is being driven mad by this fringe benefits tax and estimates of the expected extra costs to it vary between $40m and $70m. Imagine the jobs impact that the fringe benefits tax will have on the Mount Isa mine in Queensland, for example, which made only a $25m profit over the last two years combined. That alone indicates a return on capital invested of only a fraction of one per cent. Now Mount Isa Mines and, incidentally, many other mining companies around Australia will have to pay fringe benefits tax on accommodation, with anomalous remote area allowance differences between housing and board and lodging yet to be dealt with. Fringe benefits tax will have to be paid on cheap meals given to workers there. Fringe benefits tax will also have to be paid on relocation expenses. Relocation is a frequent occurrence in the mining industry, especially with skilled labour. Relocation expenses are hardly a benefit to people. Certainly it is not a rort as the Government is trying to claim. The mines already have substantial costs with relocation, but now in that regard they will have to pay fringe benefits tax on fares, temporary accommodation, agent's commission on the sale of a house and on a purchase at the other end, legal fees, stamp duty, packing, insurance, even the removal and kennelling of pets, for goodness sake. They will also have to pay tax on the re-registration of vehicles at the destination of relocation. Certainly jobs will have to be shed to pay for this tax.

It is no wonder that people in the bush are in revolt. The Australian Labor Party will not hold a country seat after the next election. We will not have a Labor member for Hunter, thank heavens. We will not have one for Calare. There will not be one for Eden-Monaro, Leichhardt or Rankin-and certainly not Capricornia. To illustrate this, I woke up this morning, turned on my television set and heard a fellow reading out the results of a poll that had just been taken. The poll indicated that Hawke has gone. He has broken just about every promise imaginable. Let me read honourable members one of them:
Let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion . . . there will be no new capital gains tax.

The only thing the Prime Minister breaks more than his promises is his wind, as he regurgitates his worn out policies in this chamber day after day. People switch off when he talks now. He has lost the goodwill he once enjoyed from the people of Australia because no one can trust him any more. What did this morning's television report on this poll say about the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? It said that he is a cheat, a liar and a funeral director, for goodness sake. I do not know why it said a funeral director--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member cannot use the device of quoting to make an allegation. He will withdraw those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) gained national prominence some time ago because he was drinking 2,4,5-T. After having listened to the diatribe that he just poured forth in this chamber, I think he is still on it. Let us come back to some of the facts about what he said so that the people listening to this debate can make their own judgment. He made some wild comments about the funding of organisations. A similar wild comment was made in this House recently about the funding of a gay publication in Victoria. It was found that the money was actually given to the organisation by a Liberal State government. Allegations were also made in this chamber about moneys being given to an organisation of lesbians in New South Wales which produced a document. It was found that the publication took place in 1978 under the Liberal-National Party Federal Government, the Fraser-Howard Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member made some wild comments about fuel costs. Let us go back to the facts and figures. The Federal Government controls the wholesale price of fuel. When the Fraser Government came to power the wholesale price was just over 11c a litre; when it left the treasury bench it had gone up by more than 28c-an increase of 28c a litre. Under the Hawke Government the increase has been about 11c a litre. I turn to some of the other mad statements that the honourable member has been making. He made a claim before about a person who wrote to him, a Mr Ron Hansen. The honour- able member ought to get up with the facts. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), a Government member, also contacted Mr Hansen. The truth of the matter is that Mr Hansen owns a private company that employs his wife, himself and one other person and now Mr Hansen will not pay any fringe benefits tax because he has cashed out the benefit to his own company and he has invested his money in his own superannuation fund. The honourable member's statement in that case was another fallacy, like so many of the nonsenses that he has brought forward.

I accept that it is the responsibility of any opposition in a democratic parliamentary system constantly to test and question the policies of government. From the ordinary citizen's point of view, this is what is expected of an opposition, but there is also an expectation, and I believe a requirement, that in testing and questioning the policies of government the opposition must also present factual, substantiated criticisms and must also put forward at the same time alternatives to the government's policies. On the issue of fringe benefits tax, this Opposition has failed on both counts because in the first instance so much of the criticism of FBT has been baseless. So many of the so-called unexpected consequences of the tax have been illusory and as an opposition it has failed outright to present any alternative policies, although I note that four or five Opposition members have been coming up with different proposals. The Opposition has tried to create fear and confusion in the minds of the community, particularly the rural community and the small business sector. At the same time, spokesman after spokesman for the Opposition has gone public contradicting other Opposition spokesmen on what they would do if the Liberal-National coalition ever got into government again.

The whole debate around the fringe benefits tax has been characterised by a phoneyness that has been matched in this country only by the debate that took place on the assets test. Honourable members will recall the outlandish claims that were made by Liberal and National politicians across the country. They said the assets test would devastate millions of pensioners. There are only 1.5 million pensioners in Australia. Yet experience has shown that only those in the high income and asset bracket have been affected. The vast majority of Australians agree with the assets test. They agree that it is proper that millionaires do not receive a pension, that those who have assets worth $600,000 or $700,000 do not receive a pension. Experience with the fringe benefits tax will show the same result. When a government introduces new legislation, especially in the tax field, there is always the risk of unintended consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—The honourable member may laugh but he should know; he was a Minister. He was involved in the presentation of legislation. Sometimes these unexpected consequences relate to unexpected loopholes. At other times it is a matter of a particular group of people being unintentionally caught up in the tax net. Should this occur-it occurs with every government across the land-it is the responsibility of that government of the day to act to redress the problems. I suppose it would be much easier if no government ever had to amend or fine tune legislation, but thinking people appreciate that when dealing with a total community, law and a million different circumstances, as can be the case with employment, problems and unexpected circumstances have to arise.

SPEECH.PARA: One has only to consider the present Income Tax Assessment Act and other relevant legislation to realise how many special exemptions, special provisions and provisos prevail in the legislation-all aimed at addressing special circumstances. Instead of being criticised for being willing to monitor and deal with the unintended consequences, this Government should be praised. This is the Government that has had the intestinal fortitude and the plain political guts to take on the problems in the taxation system-problems which existed for more than a decade under the previous Liberal Party-National Party Government; which have slowly but surely undermined the integrity of the Australian tax system; and which have been costing ordinary taxpayers on wages and fixed incomes almost $700m a year. They are the ones who have been paying-not the Government but the ordinary taxpayers.

The question that those who listen to this debate should ask themselves about fringe benefits is whether it is right and proper for a small group of Australians to be able to avoid or evade tax simply because they are paid with a salary package that is made up of a number of fringe benefits, instead of being paid in cash like everyone else. Of course it is not right, as all sorts of prominent people now agree. Two weeks ago I attended the Australian Advertising Conference on the Gold Coast. The guest speaker at its Sunday luncheon was Mr Bob Ansett. Bob Ansett, as most people realise, has been identified with the FBT debate, yet it was Bob Ansett who said at the luncheon-I will not quote him-that he was not against the principle of the fringe benefits tax. They were his words and 400 people were listening to him. He said that he challenged the way we had applied it whereby the employer paid it rather than the employee. I repeat that Bob Ansett said that he was not against the principle of the FBT. I believe that he was saying that the principle of the FBT that the Hawke Labor Government has introduced is correct. It would appear to me that, apart from the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), most coalition leaders at least have the intestinal fortitude to admit that there is a problem with FBT and that we should do something about it, because each has come out in the last few weeks publicly talking of the need to tax certain fringe benefits.

Another wild critic of the fringe benefits tax in my home State is the Premier of the National Party State Government, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. I notice that he is also against elections that do not go his own way. I hear that he said today that if he does not win the next election in his own right he will have another election. It is a great put-down of the Governor of that State that Sir Joh thinks he can do that. Sir Joh said that he and his Government are against the principle of the FBT. It seems that he has conveniently changed his mind. I have in my hand a document that has come from the State Government-I hold it up for honourable members to see-which carries the official Queensland crest. It is headed `Queensland's taxation reform package, including single rate tax proposal'. It goes on:
As presented to the National Taxation Summit in Canberra, 1-4 July, 1985 by-
I ask honourable members to listen to this-
the Honourable Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Premier and Treasurer of Queensland.

Let us not forget that he is a Treasurer when it comes to the economic disaster which that State is facing. That document under the heading `Summary' contains three very interesting tax propositions. First, Bjelke-Petersen proposes a single rate tax of 25 per cent on all income, obviously not caring about the low income earners or the pensioners. It was interesting to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Parkes on negative gearing and to hear that he was against what the Government has done, because, secondly, the Premier of Queensland advocates:
Elimination of tax shelters by quarantining negative gearing and farm losses . . .

It is amazing that the National Party of Queensland says `Let's stop negative gearing and do something about the quarantining of farm losses', but National Party members have the audacity to say in this House that it is wrong.
I come to the third and most important proposition put forward by the Queensland Premier in his document. He proposes:
A fringe benefits tax on the beneficiary (but with employers to be required to record such benefits on group certificates).

Despite what the National Party Premier of Queensland says now, because there is a pending election, he has officially proposed and advocated a fringe benefits tax. He has advocated a new and special tax on the fringe benefits that employees receive. He has advocated a new and special tax on those benefits over and above the normal wage or salary.

It is rather significant that when he proposed these other measures, such as the single tax, he added some special provisos. He said that there ought to be a rebate to replace the existing non-tax threshold. He also made a few other provisos in that regard. But when he proposed his fringe benefits tax he made no such proviso-no provisions and no exemptions. He proposes a fringe benefits tax on all employees, to be collected by all employers day by day. He proposes that they keep a complete record day by day of every benefit paid. He makes no such provisos or exemptions, such as our proviso that there is no tax payable on the first $200 in fringe benefits that a person may receive. We have a special exemption for rural housing and accommodation in country areas. But the Premier of Queensland makes no such exemptions. He has no exemptions for any circumstances, foreseen or unforeseen. Instead, he officially puts forward a fringe benefits tax, as the Premier and Treasurer of Queensland, on all Queenslanders, on all Australians. He says that there should be a tax on all fringe benefits, regardless of whether the person is being paid an allowance for his industrial clothing, shoes, tools or anything else. He is probably one who ought to talk about fringe benefits because of the $400,000 that he got. We ought to hear more about that as well. But he says that there should be no exemption for rural people who get a bit of meat and milk. The Premier of Queensland says: `No exemptions; a fringe benefits tax on everybody'. The people of Queensland ought to remember this when they go to the polls on 1 November.

In the few minutes remaining to me I will mention some of the other comments and criticisms that have been made, particularly by the National Farmers Federation. I have had a certain respect for many of the people in the National Farmers Federation. I have had the opportunity to work with some of them in my region. But I think it is rather a putdown on the people who they are supposed to represent that, when they had the opportunity to come forward to the special review that is being undertaken by this Government, they chose not to submit any proposition or submission to that review.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have lost all credibility.

—The honourable member for Petrie was supporting the National Party.

—I know; it was quite regrettable. But I think he was dealt with rather well today. The National Farmers Federation, regrettably, has made all of these sorts of strange allegations. SPEECH.PARA: There are some problems in rural areas where people must supply houses under industrial award conditions. But these are the issues that this Government is trying to address. The Government has been prepared to take hold of the problems that exist in the tax system. The Government wants to bring back some dignity and integrity to the tax system in Australia. Instead of criticising it, the Opposition ought to come up with its own alternatives. But it has not done that. It has done nothing like that. Instead, it is trying to create fear and concern in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to pay tribute to Mrs Emily Greig, nee Post, of Broken Hill. Mrs Greig will be 108 years old tomorrow. Mrs Greig was born on 18 October 1878 at Pinkerton Plains north of Adelaide. In 1898 at the age of 20 she married and moved to Broken Hill with her husband, who was looking for work in the mines. Honourable members can imagine what Broken Hill must have been like in those days-a dusty town of hessian humpies, disease and deprivation. Mrs Greig's husband died 40 years ago and so far she has outlived nine of her 10 children. Her last remaining daughter is Mrs Mildred Rodgers, who is 76 and now lives in Adelaide. Her family line includes 12 grandchildren and 25 great-grandchildren.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Greig remembers doing all her cooking on an old wood stove, scrubbing her floors and washing all her clothes by hand. No doubt honourable members will have read about those days. Until she was 106 years old, Mrs Greig did all her own washing and cooking. She has been a resident of Elleoura Lodge at the Broken Hill Base Hospital for two years. She is very well cared for. I know that all honourable members will join me in wishing Mrs Greig a very happy birthday for tomorrow and in thanking her for her great contribution, not only to Broken Hill but also to Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to my question No. 9 (Hansard, 8 October 1985, page 1555), is it a fact that of the banks and their officers who handled cheques that were part of `round-robin' tax avoidance schemes, only one investigation case made progress to the court proceedings stage; if so, why is action not being taken in other cases where similar transactions of `round-robin' arrangements were assisted by the banks and their officers.
(2) Is it a fact that provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the criminal codes could be used to bring such banks and their officers to account for these nefarious acts.
(3) What action does he intend to take against all such banks and their officers which are implicated in these tax avoidance schemes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In my answer to parts 1 and 2 of question No. 9 (Hansard, 8 October 1985, page 1555) I advised that charges had been laid against a number of persons and that court proceedings were pending in one case of the kind to which the question refers.

The Commissioner of Taxation has again advised that as far as he is aware this is the only case of this kind in which court proceedings are pending. Round-robin transactions are, in themselves, not illegal. The use of round-robin arrangements has been examined by the Courts and Boards of Review in FCT v Lau 84 ATC 4929 and Cases S 58 and S 59 85 ATC 413 and 420. No inference adverse to the taxpayer or his bankers was drawn in these cases.
However, where a round-robin transaction is found to be part of some wider transaction which is illegal, participants in the round-robin may be implicated as participants in the wider transaction.
I am advised that a decision to proceed with prosecution action in such cases is only taken after all the facts of the particular case have been examined.

(2) If it could be established by admissible evidence that any bank officer who facilitated the use of a round-robin of cheques was a party to any fraud on the Commonwealth then there may have been a breach of certain provisions of the Commonwealth Crimes Act 1914. There were no specific provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 at the time the tax avoidance schemes in question were being implemented.

(3) I am not aware of any cases where there is sufficient evidence to warrant any bank officer being charged for any offence, such as conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth, under the Crimes Act. The mere fact that the bank, through its officers, facilitates the use of a round-robin of cheques is not sufficient evidence to enable charges to be laid against the bank officers. There must at least be evidence that the bank officer were aware that the round-robin was part of a fraudulent transaction. If any such evidence is provided to me or to the Australian Taxation Office it will, of course, be forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions for his consideration.
